{{About|the literary concept|ethical shortcomings in real people|Vice}} {{Unreferenced|date=September 2008}} In the creation and criticism of fictional works, a '''character flaw''' is a limitation, imperfection, problem, [[phobia]], or deficiency present in a character who may be otherwise very functional. The flaw can be a problem that directly affects the character's actions and abilities, such as a violent temper. Alternatively, it can be a simple foible or personality defect, which affects the character's motives and social interactions, but little else.
Flaws can add depth and humanity to the characters in a [[narrative]]. For example, the sheriff with a gambling addiction, the [[action hero]] who is afraid of heights, or a lead in a [[romantic comedy]] who must overcome his insecurity regarding male pattern baldness are all characters whose flaws help provide dimension. Perhaps the most widely cited and classic of character flaws is [[Achilles]]' famous heel.
In general, flaws can be categorized as ''minor'', ''major'', or ''tragic''.
==Minor flaw== A minor character flaw is an imperfection which serves to distinguish the character in the mind of the reader / viewer / player / listener, making them memorable and individual, but otherwise does not affect the story in any way.
Examples of this could include a noticeable scar, a thick accent or a habit such as cracking their knuckles.
[[Protagonists]] and other major characters may (and usually do) have multiple minor flaws, making them more accessible, and enabling the reader / viewer / listener to relate to the character (in the case of a [[sympathetic character]]) or otherwise influence the audience's opinions of the character.
Many insignificant or archetypal characters which are encountered only once or rarely are defined solely by a single minor flaw, differentiating them from the [[stock character]] or [[archetype]] that they adhere to.
==Major flaw== A major character flaw is a much more noticeable and important hindrance which actually impairs the individual, whether physically, mentally or morally. Sometimes major flaws are not actually negative per se (such as devout religious beliefs or a rigid code of honor), but are classified as such in that they often serve to hinder or restrict the character in some way.
Examples of this type of flaw could include blindness, [[amnesia]] or greed.
Unlike minor flaws, major flaws are almost invariably important to either the character's, or the story's development.
*For villains, their major flaw is usually the cause of their eventual downfall. *For heroes, their major flaw usually must be overcome (either temporarily or permanently) at some point in the story, often at the climax, by their own determination or skill. *For neutral characters, or those that shift allegiance, the major flaw is usually the cause of either their corruption, redemption or both. *For the protagonist, the most visible flaw generally serves a more vital interest, as well, as it defines his or her core problem. It is the protagonist's reluctant (and usually unconscious) journey to address this problem that forms the spine of the story, sometimes acting as the [[MacGuffin]] to stimulate the plot.
==Tragic/fatal flaw== This is a specific sort of flaw, also known as "[[Hamartia]]", which is possessed by Aristotelian [[tragic hero]]s. It is a flaw which causes an otherwise noble or exceptional character to bring about their own downfall and, often, their eventual death.
Examples of this could include [[hubris]], misplaced trust, excessive curiosity, pride and lack of self-control.
This fall usually occurs at the beginning of a story, with the story itself concentrates on the consequences or attempted redemption of the fall.
== Examples ==
===Literature=== *[[Oedipus|Oedipus's]] downfall is directly linked to arrogance: ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'' *Macbeth suffers from [[hubris]], leading to the murder of [[Duncan I of Scotland]]; he later becomes [[paranoia|paranoid]], leading him to order the deaths of [[Banquo]] and the family of [[Macduff (Macbeth)|Macduff]]: ''[[Macbeth]]'' *[[Hamlet]] is indecisive and self-doubting, which thwarts him in avenging his father's murder. *[[Victor Frankenstein]] suffers from excessive curiosity and irresponsibility, leading to the creation of the [[Frankenstein's monster|monster]] that destroys his life: ''[[Frankenstein]]'' *[[Sigurd]] has a vulnerable spot on his back, where a linden leaf fell as he was bathing in dragon's blood: ''[[Volsunga saga]]'' *[[Agamemnon]] acts in greed when he takes [[Briseis]] away from [[Achilles]], losing the warrior's support in the [[Trojan War]]: ''[[The Iliad]]''. Achilles's own flaw was his own arrogance. *[[Odysseus|Odysseus's]] flaw was an extreme [[Hubris (Ancient Greece)|hubris]] which led him to dishonor the god [[Poseidon]]. (''[[The Odyssey]]'') *[[Cyrano De Bergerac]], despite his many accomplishments, suffers from self-doubt because of his huge nose which keeps him from pursuing the woman he loves. *[[Marvin the Paranoid Android]] suffers from extreme depression, as well as extreme boredom due to his huge yet mostly inactive mind: ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'' *[[Tom Riddle|Tom Riddle's]] extreme [[thanatophobia]] eventually transformed him into the vile Lord Voldemort in his pursuit for [[immortality]]. (''[[Harry Potter]]'') *[[Harry Potter]]'s worst flaws, as stated by Rowling, are "anger and occasional arrogance." However, within the text, it is implied his flaw might be his heroic desire to save people. (''[[Harry Potter]]'') *[[Percy Jackson]] has a fatal flaw of excessive personal loyalty, while his girlfriend Annabeth Chase shares the flaw of the legendary Odysseus: hubris. (''[[Percy Jackson and the Olympians]]'') *[[Jo March]]'s bluntness and hot temper cause conflict with her family. ''[[Little Women]]'' *In the ''[[Star Wars Expanded Universe|Star Wars Legends]]'' continuity, [[Jacen Solo|Jacen Solo's]] eventual downfall is linked to his placing the weight of the galaxy on his shoulder in his desire for peace.
===Film=== *In ''[[Rocky]]'', [[Rocky Balboa]] thinks of himself as a loser who cannot go the distance in the boxing ring. *[[Anakin Skywalker]]'s anger and fear of losing his wife [[Padme Amidala|Padme]] eventually consumes him, leading to his transformation into [[Darth Vader]]. Whereas his mentor [[Obi-Wan Kenobi|Obi-Wan Kenobi's]] compassion and love for his student blinded him to the path Skywalker was taking. (''[[Star Wars]]'') *In ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', Rick thinks of himself as an unfeeling cynic who denies the pain and disappointment from a failed love affair with Ilsa. *In ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'', the detective played by [[James Stewart]] is afraid of heights and has to climb a tower. *[[Captain Hook]] is obsessed with ''[[Peter Pan]]'' *[[Characters in Blade Runner#Roy Batty|Roy Batty]], as a replicant, is powerful, but has a very short lifespan: ''[[Blade Runner]]'' *[[Oskar Schindler]] in the film ''[[Schindler's List]]'' must overcome his greedy nature and find compassion to sacrifice in order to save his workers
===Television=== *[[B. A. Baracus]] is afraid of flying: ''[[The A-Team]]'' *[[Homer Simpson]] is an alcoholic, not too bright and prone to reckless choices: ''[[The Simpsons]]'' *[[Philip J. Fry]] (usually) has a severe lack of intelligence: ''[[Futurama]]'' *[[Londo Mollari]] yearns to return to the "glory days" of the [[Centauri Republic]]: ''[[Babylon 5]]'' *[[Mr. Spock]] relies heavily on logic and suppresses his more human emotions: ''[[Star Trek]]'' *[[Drake Mallard|Darkwing Duck/Drake Mallard]] has a big ego. ''[[Darkwing Duck]]'' *[[Peter Griffin]] is extremely impulsive and causes many problems for his family and friends: ''[[Family Guy]]'' *[[Zuko]] makes misguided decisions in an effort to gain his cruel father's acceptance: ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' *[[Aang]] is too carefree and initially attempts to run from his responsibilities rather than face them: ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' *[[Dean Winchester]] relies on family and is devastated when he loses them or they betray his trust: ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]'' *[[The Tenth Doctor]] is constantly trying to help and save the lives of others, and sometimes does things out of anger that have dire consequences later: ''[[Doctor Who]]'' *[[Mr. Gold|Rumplestiltskin's]] greatest character flaw was his greed, losing even those who love him over his mad desire for power. He shares this flaw with his former student and lover [[Cora Mills|Cora]]. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *[[Zelena (Once Upon a Time)|Zelena's]] envy of her younger half-sister [[Regina Mills]] eventually transformed her into the infamous [[Wicked Witch of the West]] as she planned to reverse time and supplant Regina. Even after this plan was thwarted, her envy remained a great character flaw throughout her time on the show. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *After the death of her fiance Daniel Colter, [[Regina Mills|Regina]] suffered a mental breakdown and became consumed with anger, which Rumplestiltskin was able to use to shape her into the Evil Queen who would cast his Dark Curse. Anger, as a fatal flaw, is one she shares with [[Hook (Once Upon a Time)|Killian Jones]] whose own anger transformed him into vengeful [[Captain Hook]]; however, Hook did not share Regina's mental instability. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *The main character flaw of the protagonist of the series, [[Emma Swan]], are her tendency to mistrust other people, which leads her to put up emotional barriers to protect herself and run when things get difficult. Her overcoming this flaw is a major story arc on the show. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'')
===Gaming=== * In [[Warhammer 40,000]], the Primarch Lorgar Aurelian is extremely devout and reveres his "father", the Emperor of Mankind, as a god. The Emperor envisages a human civilization free of the shackles of religion and dogma and chastises Lorgar and his legion for worshipping him. Hurt and depressed by the humiliation of his father's rebuke, Lorgar and the [[Space Marines (Warhammer 40,000)|Space Marines]] of the XVII Legion (the "Word Bearers") search for another purpose to sustain them, and in doing so become the first legion to fall under the malicious influence of [[Chaos (Warhammer)|Chaos]]. Their devotion to Chaos sees them instigate the devastating civil war known as the [[Horus Heresy (fictional event)|Horus Heresy]], the events of which led to the current dystopian setting of Warhammer 40,000. *In ''[[Metal Gear Solid]]'', Liquid's jealousy of Solid Snake's "dominant genes" and his desire to be the better of the two sets much of the story in motion, leading to Liquid's eventual downfall. *In the ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' series, [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] acts brutally and violently out of anger and desire for revenge, with devastating consequences on his only life and the world around him.
[[Category:Fictional characters| ]] [[Category:Fiction]]

page.title: Coat of arms of the Prince of Asturias

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox coat of arms | image = Coat of Arms of Leonor, Princess of Asturias.svg | image_width = 180 | armiger = [[Leonor, Princess of Asturias]] | year_adopted = 30 October 2015 | crest = [[Crown (heraldry)|Crown]] of the Princess of Asturias | shield = [[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]]: [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|Castile]], [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|León]], [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; ''enté en point'', [[Granada]]; [[inescutcheon]][[National Emblem of France|Bourbon (Anjou Branch)]]; the whole differenced by a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] [[azure (heraldry)|azure]]. | orders = [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] | earlier_versions = ''See below'' }} The [[blazon]] of the '''[[coat of arms]] of the [[Princess of Asturias]]''' is given by a Royal Decree 979 on 30 October 2015 which was an amendment of the Royal Decree 1511 dated [[Madrid]] 21 January 1977, which also created her guidon (military personal ensign) and her standard.{{cite web|title=Boletín Oficial del Estado|url=http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2015/10/31/pdfs/BOE-A-2015-11729.pdf|accessdate=31 October 2015|language=Spanish}} ==Official blazon== The shield is divided into four quarters, blazoned as follows: *1st, [[Gules]] a castle three-towered [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], masoned [[Sable]] ajoure, (door and windows) [[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]], for [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]]; *2nd, [[Argent]] a lion rampant Purpure crowned Or, armed Gules and crowned Or, for [[Kingdom of León|León]]; *3rd, Or four pallets Gules, for [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]]; *4th, Gules a cross, saltire and orle of chains all linked Or, an emerald Proper, for [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; *''Enté en point'', Argent a pomegranate Proper seeded Gules, supported, sculpted and leafed in two leaves [[Vert (heraldry)|Vert]], for [[Granada]]; *[[Inescutcheon]], Azure with three [[fleurs-de-lys]] Or, [[bordure]]d Gules, for [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]]. The whole is differenced by a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points Azure, the [[brisure|difference]] used by heirs apparent to the [[House of Habsburg|Spanish House of Habsburg]]. The shield is surmounted by a closed crown, which is a circle of gold, inset with precious stones of their colours, composed of eight rosettes of acanthus leaves, of which five are visible, interspersed by pearls in their colour, issuing from which are four pearl diadems, of which three are visible, which converge in a blue orb, with gold semi-meridian and equator, surmounted by a gold cross, the crown lined with red and surrounded by the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece|Golden Fleece]]. ==History== {| width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- | {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- |colspan = "3" bgcolor = "#ccccff" align="center"|''' Historical Arms of Princes and Princesses of Asturias''' |- !width = "35%"|Arms !width = "20%"|Dates !width = "45%"|Details |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Heir of the Crown of Castile (1230-1284).svg|130px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Heir of the Crown of Castile (1284-1390).svg|130px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1390-15th Century).svg|130px]]
||1388–1468||The arms used in the 13th and 14th century by the Prince of Asturias, and the others heirs apparent to the [[Crown of Castile|Castilian]] Throne before the title was adopted, were the [[Undifferenced arms|undifferenced Royal Arms]]. However, the '' [[Infante]]s'' used differenced arms.Francisco Olmos, José María de [http://www.ucm.es/info/documen/articulos/art_tercera/art_chema.pdf Las primeras acuñaciones del príncipe Felipe de España (1554–1556): Soberano de Milán Nápoles e Inglaterra. The First Coins of Prince Felipe of Spain (1554–1556): Sovereign of Milan, Naples and England. pp.165–166] {{es icon}}Rodríguez de Maribona, Manuel [http://www.abc.es/informacion/boda/biografia_principe/07f.asp Las armas del Príncipe de Asturias – ABC]. {{es icon}} Accessed 2009-05-28. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Isabella of Castile as Princess of Asturias (with crest).svg|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Isabella of Castile as Princess of Asturias.svg|150px]]|| 1468–1474|| [[Isabella I of Castile|Princess Isabella]] (Isabella I as Queen of Castile) used the undifferenced Castilian Royal Arms and added the [[Eagle (heraldry)#Eagle of Saint John|Saint John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle]], an [[Eagle (heraldry)|eagle "displayed"]] as single [[supporter]]. In 1473 the Princess Isabella's seal bearing her arms without crest and the St John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle.{{cite book |last= |first= |title=Isabel la Católica en la Real Academia de la Historia |year=2004 |publisher= Real Academia de la Historia |location=Madrid |page=72|ISBN=84-95983-54-0 }}Princess of Isabella's coat of arms with crest: {{cite journal | last1 =García-Menacho Osset | first1 =Eduardo |date = | year =2010 | title =El origen militar de los símbolos de España. El escudo de España|trans-title=Military Origin of Symbols of Spain. The Coat of Arms of Spain| journal =Revista de Historia Militar | issue =Extra | series = |page=387 | location = | publisher =Instituto de Historia y Cultura Militar | language =Spanish | issn = 0482-5748}} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of John of Aragon and Castile, Prince of Asturias and Girona (with crest).svg|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of John of Aragon and Castile, Prince of Asturias and Girona.svg|150px]]|| 1478–1497||On the tomb of [[John, Prince of Asturias]] and [[Prince of Girona|Girona]] in [[Ávila, Spain#Real Monasterio de Santo Tomás|St Thomas's Royal Monastery]], sculpted by [[Domenico Fancelli]], is shown the undifferenced Catholic Monarchs's coat of arms without crest supported by the St John the ''Evangelist'''s Eagle and two [[Putto|putti]] frequently used as sculptural decoration but not heraldic supporters in Spanish royal heraldry.[http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Avila_-_Real_Monasterio_de_Santo_Tomas_21.JPG Image of the coat of arms on Prince John's tomb]. |- |align="center" colspan="2"| 1506–1516||When the [[House of Habsburg]] inherited the Crowns of Castile and Aragon marks of [[Cadency]] – a [[label (heraldry)|label]] of three points – were added to the heirs apparent's arms, as was usual in the heraldry of many European monarchies. Prince [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles]] (Charles I as King of Spain and Charles V as Holy Roman Emperor) used his father's arms – ''A quartered shield, depicting [[Austria]], new [[Burgundy (region)|Burgundy]], old Burgundy, [[Duchy of Brabant|Brabant]] and [[Coat of arms of Flanders|Flanders]] on an escutcheon'' – with a label argent. These arms weren’t used as Prince of Asturias because Prince Charles didn’t add the arms of Castile and Aragon.{{cite book |last= Menéndez-Pidal De Navascués |first= Faustino |title=El Escudo de España |year=2004 |publisher= Real Academia Matritense de Heráldica y Genealogía |location=Madrid |pages=191–192|ISBN=84-88833-02-4 }} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1527-1554).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1527-1554).svg|border|150px]]
||1528–1556|| Prince [[Philip II of Spain|Philip]] (Philip II as King of Spain and Philip I of Portugal) used his father's arms differenced with a label argent or azure. The Prince Philip's arms are shown on many Prince's [[armour]]s. Now these armours have been kept at the Royal Armoury in the [[Royal Palace of Madrid]]. Sometimes, Philip also used the undifferenced arms of his father. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1560-1578).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1560-1578).svg|border|150px]]
||1560–1568|| In 1568 Prince [[Carlos, Prince of Asturias|Carlos]], the eldest son of Philip II, died and an [[Ambrosio Morales]]'s report for the Prince's [[sepulchre]] said his arms were the Royal Arms but with "''a label azure with its three short points".'' Prince Carlos also used the royal arms differenced with a label argent. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Philip of Austria, Prince of Asturias-Argen Label Wavy Variant (1580-1598).svg|border|180px]]
||1584–1598|| Prince [[Philip III of Spain|Philip]] (Philip III as King of Spain and Philip II of Portugal) sometimes used a new label argent variant wavy azure. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Azur Label (1580-1665).svg|border|150px]] [[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias-Argen Label (1580-1665).svg|border|150px]]
||1608–1665||The eldest son of Philip III, Prince [[Philip IV of Spain|Philip]] (Philip IV as King of Spain and Philip III of Portugal), used the Royal Arms with label argent or azure. Philip's son, Prince [[Balthasar Charles, Prince of Asturias|Balthasar Charles]] also bore the same differences. |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1700-1761)-Version with Golden Fleece and Holy Spirit Collars.svg|border|150px]]
[[File:Coat of Arms of the Prince of Asturias (1761-1868 and 1874-1931)-Golden Fleece and Order of Charles III Variant.svg|border|150px]]
||1707–1761
1761–1931|| The shields of the [[House of Bourbon]]'s heirs apparent hardly ever depicted differences. [[Cronista Rey de Armas|Chronicler King of Arms]] Juan José Vilar y Psayla (1830–1894) said the arms of the Prince of Asturias were differentiated by a crown of four-half-arches, the Spanish monarch's crown has eight-half-arches since the reign of [[Philip V of Spain|Philip V]] (1700–1746). |- |align="center" colspan="2"|1971-1975
''1977-2001
(De facto without use)''[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/es%5Epri71.html Standard of the Heir Prince 1971-1975, possibly also 1982-2001 (Spain). [[Flags of the World|FOTW]]]. Retrieved 18 February 2016.||{{further|Coat of arms of the Prince of Spain}} |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Felipe, Prince of Asturias (2001-2014).svg|border|150px]]
||2001–2014|| The coat of arms used by the future King [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] as Prince of Asturias had the [[Coat of Arms of the King of Spain|royal arms of Spain]] differenced by a label of three points Azure, this recovered difference has been used by heirs apparent to the Spanish House of Habsburg. Prince Felipe's coat of arms was adopted by the Royal Decree 284 dated Madrid 16 March 2001, which also created his Guidon and Standard.{{cite web|title=Boletín Oficical del Estado|url=http://www.boe.es/buscar/doc.php?id=BOE-A-2001-5302|accessdate=1 November 2015|language=Spanish}} |- |} |} ==See also== *[[Coat of arms of the King of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of the Prince of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of Spain]] *[[Royal Standard of Spain]] *[[Coat of arms of the Prince of Wales]] ==Notes== *On sepulchres of Habsburg Princes of Asturias who didn't ascend to the throne their coats of arms are the undifferenced Lesser Royal Arms (''Quarterly, 1 and 4 [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], 2 and 3 [[Kingdom of León|León]]''), with a crown closed with four-half-arches in crest. The Pantheon of the Princes of the [[El Escorial|Royal Seat of El Escorial]] was completed in 1888, in the nineteenth century the heir to the Spanish throne used Royal Arms differentiated by a crown of four-half-arches.{{cite AV media |people=Bazhe |year= |title=Royal Pantheon El Escorial |trans-title= |medium= |language= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KVf7LlonKyw |accessdate=3 January 2012 |archiveurl= |archivedate= |format= |time= 8:12publisher=You Tube |location= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Spanish coat of arms}} [[Category:Personal coats of arms|Prince of Asturias]] [[Category:Spanish coats of arms|Prince of Asturias]] [[Category:Spanish monarchy]] [[Category:Princes of Asturias]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with buildings|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with chains|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with lions|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with fleurs de lis|Asturias, Prince]] [[Category:Coats of arms with the Golden Fleece|Asturias, Prince]]

page.title: Coat of arms of the Prince of Wales

revision.comment: /* Heir Apparent */ Ch. "James IV" to "James VI" in para. 1610-1688
revision.text:
{{Infobox Coat of arms |name = Coat of Arms of the Prince of Wales |image = Coat of Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg |image_width = 270 |middle = Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg |middle_width = 100 |middle_caption = Escutcheon of the [[Prince of Wales]] |armiger = [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] |year_adopted = 1958 |crest = A golden lion difference with a white [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points, crowned with the [[Coronet]] of the [[Heir apparent]] and standing on the same coronet; gold and ermine mantling.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry#chapter-wrapper-2 |title=Titles and Heraldry: Coat of Arms |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} |shield = The [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom|Royal Arms]] difference with a white label of three points; with an inescutcheon of four lions passant guardant, in gold and red, counterchanged (for the [[Principality of Wales]]). |supporters = A golden lion, wearing the coronet of the Heir apparent, and a silver unicorn, both difference with a white label of three points. |motto = {{lang-de|[[Ich dien]]}} |orders = [[Order of the Garter]] |other_elements = [[Heraldic badge|Badges]]: [[Prince of Wales's feathers]], [[Welsh dragon]] with a white label of three points and crowned escutcheon of the [[Duchy of Cornwall]]. |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''coat of arms of the Prince of Wales''' is the official [[Heraldry|heraldic]] insignia of the [[Prince of Wales]], a title traditionally granted to the [[heir apparent]] to the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|reigning monarch]] of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland]], formerly the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and before that the [[Kingdom of England]]. The [[coat of arms]], in its current form, was devised for [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] in 1958. It contains the badges and elements taken from all four of the [[Countries of the United Kingdom|constituent countries of the United Kingdom]] as well as from the many [[List of titles and honours of Charles, Prince of Wales|titles the prince holds]] as [[heir apparent]]. The history of the coat of arms is closely linked with that of the [[Royal Arms of England|Royal coat of arms of England]] and the [[Royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]]. However, as the noted antiquarian and heraldist [[Charles Boutell]] wrote in 1863, "The Arms of the Prince of Wales have a distinct individuality of their own, with which nothing ought to be directly associated."Boutell p. 256 ==Elements== ====Coronet==== [[File:Ströhl-Regentenkronen-Fig. 31.png|thumb|130px|left|The British heir-apparent's coronet as depicted by [[Hugo Gerard Ströhl]]]] The [[Coronet|coronets of the Prince and the Peers]] of the realm were regulated by King [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] by Royal Warrant, signed on 9 February 1661. Part of the warrant proclaimed: "Our Will and Pleasure therefore is, That the Son and Heir Apparent of the Crown for the time being, shall use and bear his Coronet composed of Crosses and [[Fleur-de-lis|Flower-de-Lized]] with one Arch; and in the midst a [[Globus cruciger|Ball and Cross]], as hath our Royal Diadem".{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/prince_highness_docs.htm#The_Warrant_of_1661 |title=Warrant of Feb 9, 1661|accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=www.heraldica.org}} In other words, the heraldic coronet used in the Prince of Wales's coat of arms is similar to the [[Crown (heraldry)|heraldic crown]] ([[St. Edward's crown]]) used in the Royal arms, except that instead of two intersecting arches it has only one. Boutell wrote that: "It should be noticed, however, that this coronet belongs to the prince as eldest son of the Sovereign and heir-apparent to the Throne, and not as Prince of Wales". The coronet is also used by the Prince of Wales's consort, in her coat of arms.Boutell p. 363 The heir's coronet was confirmed in another Royal Warrant signed on 19 November 1917 by King [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. The warrant proclaimed: "by the son and heir apparent of the sovereign and his successors a coronet composed of crosses and fleurs-de-lis with one arch and in the midst a ball and cross as in the royal crown."{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldica.org/topics/britain/prince_highness_docs.htm#Warrant_of_Nov_19_1917 |title=Warrant of Nov 19, 1917|accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=www.heraldica.org}} Currently there are three physical examples of coronets used at one time or other as part of the [[Honours of the Principality of Wales]]; the [[Coronet of Frederick, Prince of Wales|Coronet of Frederick]], the [[Coronet of George, Prince of Wales|Coronet of George]] and the [[Coronet of Charles, Prince of Wales|Coronet of Charles]]. However these physical manifestations have not affected the graphical representation of the coronet in heraldic art.{{Cite web |url=https://www.royal.uk/honours-principality-wales |title=Honours of the Principality of Wales |website=www.royal.uk |access-date=2018-10-15}} ====Label==== Beginning with the reign of King [[Edward I of England|Edward I]], a [[Label (heraldry)|label]] of three points [[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]] (or blue) was used by his son, the future King [[Edward II of England|Edward II]], to differentiate his arms from those of his father. Without such a label their arms would be identical. Within [[heraldry]] this system of differentiating arms is called [[cadency]]. The label is placed on the [[Chief (heraldry)|chief]] (or top) of the [[shield]] of arms, with the ends extending across from the dexter to the sinister sides of the shield. It was Prince [[Edward the Black Prince]], heir of King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]], who first used a label of three points [[Argent]], also white or silver. This has been the label of the heir apparent ever since, without regard to the system of [[Cadency labels of the British royal family|cadency used by other members]] of the royal family.Boutell p. 187 ====Crest==== [[File:Prince of Wales 1914.png|thumb|200px|right|Coat of arms of [[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom|Edward, Prince of Wales]] as illustrated in [[Burke's Peerage]] 1914 edition.]] The Prince of Wales's [[Crest (heraldry)|crest]] follows closely that of the Sovereign, but always with the appropriate label of [[Cadency|difference]] displayed. This crest depicts a "Lion [[Or (heraldry)|Or]], passant guardant, wearing a coronet of the Heir, and differenced on the shoulders with a label of three points Argent." The lion always stands on a larger coronet of the Heir, which then sits on a golden [[Helmet (heraldry)|helmet]] or the Royal Helm. From the sides flow the gold and [[Ermine (heraldry)|ermine]] [[mantling]] of the royal family. ====Supporters==== Similarly to the crest, the prince's [[supporter]]s follow those of the Sovereign. On either side of the shield of arms and standing on gold scrollwork are the royal supporters: the [[Lion and the Unicorn]]. Both beasts have the prince's label charged around their necks, again as an appropriate mark of difference. The [[Lion (heraldry)|lion]] on the [[Dexter and sinister|dexter side]], an [[National symbols of England|ancient symbol of England]], is crowned with the coronet of the Heir. The beast has been a [[Royal Supporters of England|supporter of the English royal arms]] since the reign of King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]. The white [[Unicorn#Heraldry|unicorn]] of [[Scotland]] on the [[Dexter and sinister|sinister side]], was incorporated into the royal arms from the [[Royal coat of arms of Scotland|Scottish royal arms]] after the Union of the crowns in 1603. ====Order==== Prince Charles was appointed a [[List of current members of the Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]] in 1958. Since the founding of the Order in 1348, almost every Prince of Wales has been appointed to the Order.Boutell p. 265 The [[Order of the Garter]] is represented in the coat of arms by its namesake the blue buckled [[Garter (stockings)|garter]], which bears in gold letters the motto, ''[[Honi soit qui mal y pense]]'', [[French language|French]] for "Shame upon him who thinks evil of it". ====Motto==== Under the coat of arms is a scroll bearing the [[motto]] ''[[Ich dien]]'', German for "I serve". The motto of uncertain origin first appeared on the arms of [[Edward, the Black Prince|Edward of Woodstock]], or the Black Prince. Prince Edward was created Prince of Wales by his father King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] on 12 May 1343. Legend holds that the Black Prince took the motto as well as the ostrich feathers from King [[John of Bohemia|John the Blind of Bohemia]], who was killed fighting alongside the prince and his father at the [[Battle of Crécy]] in 1346. The motto is also a near [[homophone]] for ''Eich Dyn'', "Your Man" in [[Welsh language|Welsh]].Scott-Giles p. 75 ===Badges=== {| style="float:right; width:170px; border:solid #ccc 1px; margin:5px;" |- align="center" |[[File:Prince of Wales's feathers Badge.svg|150px]] |- align="center" |The [[Prince of Wales's feathers]] badge |- align="center" |[[File:Prince of Wales' Red Dragon.svg|150px]] |- align="center" |The [[Welsh Dragon|Welsh red dragon]] badge with a white label of three points |- align="center" |[[File:Arms of the Duchy of Cornwall.svg|90px]] |- align="center" |The arms of [[Cornwall]] with coronet |} The Prince of Wales as part of his full achievement of arms has many [[Heraldic badge]]s, which represents the history and sovereignty of his many titles. ====Prince of Wales' feathers==== {{Main|Prince of Wales's feathers}} The Prince of Wales's feathers badge comprises "A plume of three [[ostrich]] feathers Argent enfiled by a royal coronet of alternate crosses and fleur-de-lys Or" with the motto 'Ich Dien' on a dark blue ribbon. The badge is probably the most recognisable element of the Prince of Wales's coat of arms. It has become synonymous as a personal insignia of the prince and also of the [[Principality of Wales]] itself.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry|title=Titles and Heraldry: Prince of Wales's Feathers |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} In a personal capacity the badge is granted as a [[Royal Warrant of Appointment (United Kingdom)|Royal Warrant of Appointment]] to companies that regularly supply of goods and services to the Prince. Currently there are 170 companies which are entitled to display this badge with the words 'By Appointment to HRH The Prince of Wales' underneath. The badge can be depicted on all premises, delivery vehicles, stationery and advertisements as well as on the individual products themselves.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/titles-and-heraldry |title=Titles and Heraldry: Royal Warrants |accessdate=2018-08-10 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}} Other organisations associated with Wales or the prince incorporate the badge into their own insignia including many Welsh regiments of the [[British Army]] (such as the [[Royal Regiment of Wales]]) and the [[Welsh Rugby Union]].Scott-Giles p. 18 Feathers used as either a crest or a badge have been an [[Royal badges of England|ancient heraldic badge]] of the [[House of Plantagenet]]. However it was not until its incorporation into the heraldic achievements of the Black Prince that the feathers have become an omnipresent feature of the coats of arms of the Prince of Wales.Scott-Giles pp. 89–93 ====Red Dragon of Wales==== {{Main|Royal Badge of Wales}} On 10 December 1901 a warrant signed by King [[Edward VII]] approved the addition of a badge of the [[Welsh Dragon|Red Dragon]] to the coat of arms of the Prince of Wales. The proclamation stated that: "on the sinister side a representation of the [[Royal badge of Wales|Badge of Wales]], namely, on a mount vert a Dragon, passant [[gules]], differenced (as in the Crest) with a label of three points argent." This was to complement the feathers badge, which was to be depicted on the dexter side of the prince's crest.{{LondonGazette|issue=27385 |date=10 December 1901 |page=8714 }} The Red Dragon, or ''Y Ddraig Goch'', has been a symbol associated with Wales since the time of [[Cadwaladr]], [[Kingdom of Gwynedd|King of Gwynedd]] in the 7th century. It was not until the beginning of the [[House of Tudor]] that the Red Dragon became a royal badge of the kings of England. Henry Tudor (later King [[Henry VII of England|Henry VII]]) displayed the Dragon of Cadwaladr on his [[Royal standards of England|battle standard]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.flaginstitute.org/pdfs/Robin%20Ashburner.pdf |title=Flags in Wales |last=Ashburner |first=Robin |date=2001 |website=flaginstitute.org |access-date=2018-10-15}} The red dragon became an official royal badge of the sovereign (representing Wales) according to a warrant issued in 1801. The warrant at the same time also confirmed the [[Tudor rose]] as a royal badge for England, the [[thistle]] for Scotland and the [[Celtic harp|golden harp]] for Ireland.Pinces & Pinces p. 216 ====Arms of the Duchy of Cornwall==== {{Main|Duke of Cornwall}} The arms of the Duke of Cornwall are: "[[Sable (heraldry)|Sable]], fifteen [[bezant]]s, five, four, three, two and one." These arms were derived from those of [[Richard, 1st Earl of Cornwall]], [[King of the Romans]], son and heir of King [[John, King of England|John]], who was also [[Count of Poitiers]] (or [[Poitou]]), represented by arms made up of [[pea]]s (poix) or [[gold coin]]s.{{cite book |last=Fox-Davis |first=Arthur Charles|authorlink=Arthur Charles Fox-Davies |title=The Book Of Public Arms. A Complete Encyclopaedia Of All Royal, Territorial, Municipal, Corporate, Official, And Impersonal Arms |url=https://archive.org/details/bookofpublicarms00foxd/page/210 |year=1915 |publisher=T. C. & E. C. Jack |location=London |asin=B00TT2UM5S |pages=210}}Scott-Giles p. 70 Upon the accession of the prince's mother as Queen [[Elizabeth II]] on 6 February 1952, Prince Charles was automatically made the [[Duke of Cornwall]]. As such he is able to display the arms of the duchy on his coat of arms.{{cite book |last=Burke's Peerage|first= |authorlink=Burke's Peerage |title=Burke's guide to the Royal Family (Burke's genealogical series)|url=https://archive.org/details/burkesguidetoroy00lond/page/136 |year=1973 |publisher=Burke's Peerage; 1st edition |location=London |isbn=0220662223|pages=137}} This title has been granted to every heir apparent since 17 March 1337, in accordance with a charter issued by King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]] for Prince [[Edward the Black Prince]], his eldest son and heir.{{cite book |last=Burke's Peerage|first= |authorlink=Burke's Peerage |title=Burke's genealogical and heraldic history of peerage, baronetage and knightage |url=https://archive.org/details/bub_gb_Pf8cAAAAYAAJ/page/n213 |year=1914 |publisher=Burke's Peerage |location=London |isbn=|pages=16}} ==Escutcheon== ===Independent Prince=== {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- !width = "14%"|Arms !width = "10%"|Dates !width = "26%"|Princes !width = "50%"|Information |- |
[[File:Arms of Llywelyn.svg|100px]]
||c.1240 – 1282|| * [[Dafydd ap Llywelyn]] * [[Llywelyn the Last|Llywelyn ap Gruffydd]] the Last ||The arms of Gwynedd or Llywelyn ap Gruffydd were the arms of the princes of North Wales; the arms are blazoned as: ''"[[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]] Or and Gules, four lions passant guardant counterchanged."''Pinces & Pinces p. 273 |- |
[[File:Arms of Dafydd ap Gruffydd.svg|100px]]
||c.1282 – 1283|| * [[Dafydd ap Gruffydd]] ||The arms of Dafydd ap Gruffydd were the arms of the last independent prince of Wales, before his execution at the hands of King [[Edward I of England]] in 1283. His arms are the same as those of Llywelyn, but with Azure replacing Gules.Pinces & Pinces p. 173{{Cite web |url=https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/dafydd-ap-gruffydds-outlawed-lions-2759658 |title=Dafydd ap Gruffydd’s outlawed lions return on coat of arms |date=2018-03-01 |website=North Wales Daily Post |access-date=2018-10-16}} |- |
[[File:Arms of Owain Glyndŵr.svg|100px]]
||1404 – c.1415|| * [[Owain Glyndŵr]] ||The arms of Owain Glyndŵr were supposedly based on those of the houses of [[House of Dinefwr|Dinefwr]] and [[House of Mathrafal|Mathrafal]]. Blazoned as: ''"Quarterly or and gules, four lions rampant armed and langued azure counterchanged."'' Glyndŵr unsuccessfully led the [[Glyndŵr Rising]] for Welsh independence that was crushed in 1415 during the reign of King [[Henry V of England|Henry V]].Scott-Giles p. 74 |- |} ===Heir Apparent=== {| width = "100%" border = 1 border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- !width = "14%"|Arms !width = "10%"|Dates !width = "26%"|Princes (later as King) !width = "50%"|Information |- |
[[File:Arms_of_Edward,_Prince_of_Wales_(1301-1307).svg|100px]]
||1303 – 1307|| * Edward of Caernarfon ([[Edward II of England]]) ||{{cquote|E portroit, o un bleu label
Les armes le bon roi son pere.
Or li doint Dieus grace ke il pere
Ausi vaillans, e non pas meins; }} Translated as: "Arms he bore of the good King his father, with a label azure. May God grant him grace and courage to his royal father’s measure!" The quote is from a contemporary poem of the siege of [[Caerlaverock Castle|Caerlaverock]] in 1300.{{cite web |url=https://www.theheraldrysociety.com/articles/the-siege-of-caerlaverock/ |title=The Siege of Caerlaverock |accessdate=2018-10-09 |work=The Heraldry Society}}{{cite book |last=Wright|first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Wright (antiquarian) |title=The Roll of Arms of the Princes, Barons, and Knights who Attended King Edward I to the Siege of Caerlaverock, in 1300 |url=https://archive.org/details/rollofarmsofprin00wrigrich/ |year=1864 |publisher=J.C. Hotten |location=Londone |isbn=0-900455-25-X|pages=18}} The poem refers to Prince Edward (the future of Edward II), who was born in 1284 at [[Caernarfon Castle]] and was then presented to the Welsh chiefs by his father King [[Edward I of England|Edward I]] as their Prince. However it was not until seventeen years later that he was presented with the title of Prince of Wales. His arms depicted the arms of the [[Kingdom of England]] with a label of three points Azure.Pinces & Pinces p. 48Boutell p. 191 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Ancient).svg|100px]]
||1343 – 1377|| * [[Edward, the Black Prince|Edward of Woodstock]], the Black Prince * Richard of Bordeaux ([[Richard II of England]]) ||[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Shield of Peace).svg|100px|right|thumb|Shield of Peace]] Edward, the Black Prince's arms were: ''"Quarterly France ancien'' (reflecting King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]]'s [[English claims to the French throne|claim to the French throne]]) ''and England with a label of three points Argent"''. This shield is often called his 'Shield for War'; additionally a scroll with the [[French language|French]] word ''Houmont'' (or Magnanimous) appears above the shield. On his tomb however an additional shield of arms was also displayed, the 'Shield for Peace': ''"Sable, three ostrich feathers, their quils passing through escrolls Argent bearing the words 'Ich Dien'"''; the same motto also appears above the shield in another scroll.Brooke-Little p.77 The future Richard II was granted the shield for war as his arms when he was created Prince of Wales, a few months after the death of his father in 1376.Pinces & Pinces p. 61 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (Modern).svg|100px]]
||1399 – 1509|| * Henry of Monmouth ([[Henry V of England]]) * [[Edward of Westminster]] * Edward of the Sanctuary ([[Edward V of England]]) * [[Edward of Middleham, Prince of Wales|Edward of Middleham]] * [[Arthur, Prince of Wales|Arthur Tudor]] * Henry Tudor, Duke of York ([[Henry VIII of England]]) ||Mirroring the changes in the Royal arms, as brought about by King [[Henry IV of England|Henry IV]], who changed the 1st and 4th quarter from [[National Emblem of France|France ancien to France moderne]]. This version was first granted to the future Henry V.Pinces & Pinces p. 94 The arms were then used by various Princes of Wales from both the [[House of Lancaster|Houses of Lancaster]] (Edward of Westminster) and [[House of York|York]] (the future Edward V and Edward of Middleham).Pinces & Pinces p. 124 The arms remained unchanged during the [[House of Tudor|Tudor dynasty]] when the title was granted to Arthur Tudor in 1489. With his death in 1502, the arms were re-granted to his brother, the future Henry VIII, in 1504.Pinces & Pinces p. 139 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Stuart Princes of Wales (1610-1688).svg|100px]]
||1610 – 1688|| * [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales|Henry Frederick Stuart]] * Charles Stuart, Duke of York ([[Charles I of England]]) * Charles Stuart ([[Charles II of England]]) * ''James Stuart, Duke of York ([[James II of England]])'' * [[James Francis Edward Stuart]] ||The [[House of Stuart|Stuart succession]] brought major changes to arms by incorporating elements of the arms of Scotland and Ireland in the 2nd and 3rd quarters respectively. The arms were first granted to Henry Stuart, the Duke of Rothesay after his father [[James I of England|James VI]] ascended the throne of England as James I. The arms were then granted twice more to the future Charles I and Charles II. It has been reported that James, the Duke of York (future James II) also bore the arms (despite not holding the title Prince of Wales), but only when his position as heir-presumptive to his brother became secure after the [[Exclusion Bill|Exclusion crisis]]. The arms were once more granted to James Francis Edward, who after 1688 became the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite Pretender]], whose son [[Charles Edward Stuart|Charles Edward]] (Bonnie Prince Charlie) continued the use of the arms in exile.Pinces & Pinces pp. 170-189 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Hanoverian Princes of Wales (1714-1760).svg|100px]]
||1714 – 1801|| * George Augustus ([[George II of Great Britain]]) * [[Frederick, Prince of Wales|Frederick Louis]] * George William Frederick
([[George III of the United Kingdom]]) * George Augustus Frederick
([[George IV of the United Kingdom]]) ||[[File:Royal Hanover Inescutcheon.svg|100px|right|thumb|Arms of Hanover with the crown of Charlemagne]] The [[House of Hanover]] inherited the throne of Great Britain after the death of Queen [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]] in 1714, which led to the incorporation of the arms of King George I's possessions in [[Germany]] into the Royal arms. The blazon for the arms became: ''"1st quarter England impaling Scotland, 2nd France moderne, 3rd Ireland and 4th the [[Electorate of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Electorate of Hanover]], with a label of three points Argent. The Hanoverian quarter depicted: [[Duchy of Brunswick|Brunswick]], [[Lüneburg]], [[Duchy of Westphalia|Westphalia]] and an inescutcheon plain Gules, over all three."'' In the Royal arms the inescutcheon contained a depiction of the [[Crown of Charlemagne]], which was an [[augmentation of honour]] granted to the [[Prince-elector]]s of Hanover as [[Arch-Treasurer]] to the [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. As heir to this Imperial office, only the Prince of Wales was entitled to bear the empty inescutcheon, in right of inheritance of this imperial office.Pinces & Pinces pp. 206-229 |- |
[[File:Arms of George, Prince of Wales and Prince Regent (1762-1820).svg|100px]]
||1801 – 1820|| * George Augustus Frederick
(George IV of the United Kingdom) ||With the [[Acts of Union 1800|Act of Union of 1800]], the arms of the Prince of Wales changed with those of the Kingdom. The ancient claim to France was abandoned, and England occupied the 1st and 4th quarter, while the Hanoverian quarter became an inescutcheon at the centre of the shield. This shield of arms was granted only once to George Augustus Frederick (the future George IV), who also became [[Prince regent]] in 1811.Pinces & Pinces p. 229 |- |
[[File:Arms of the Prince of Wales (1841-1910).svg|100px]]
||1841 – 1910|| * Albert Edward
([[Edward VII of the United Kingdom]]) * George, Duke of York
([[George V of the United Kingdom]]) ||The Royal arms were once again altered following the ascension of Queen [[Queen Victoria|Victoria]] to the throne in 1837, when the Hanoverian shield was dropped. The Hanoverian inescutcheon was replaced by the [[Coat of arms of Saxony|arms of Saxony]], which was a heraldic inheritance from the queen's husband Prince [[Albert, Prince Consort|Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]] (a Duke of Saxony).Aveling p. 287Pinces & Pinces p. 259 The inescutcheon only appeared in the arms of Albert's male-line descendants, and not in the Royal arms itself. According to the antiquarian Charles Boutell, the inescutcheon was placed as an "escutcheon of pretence", that "does not appear to be in accordance with either the spirit or the practical usage of true historical Heraldry". These arms were granted twice, first to 'Bertie' (later King Edward VII) and to the future George V. In his 1909 book ''A Complete Guide to Heraldry,'' [[Arthur Charles Fox-Davies]] writes: "It is much to be regretted that the arms of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales (the future George V) do not include the arms of his sovereignty of the Duchy of Cornwall, nor any allusion to his dignities of Prince of Wales or [[Earl of Chester]]."Fox-Davies (1909) p. 486Pinces & Pinces p. 265 |- |
[[File:Arms of Charles, Prince of Wales.svg|100px]]
||1911 – present|| * Edward Albert
([[Edward VIII of the United Kingdom]]) * Charles, Prince of Wales
(''incumbent'') ||In 1910 Prince Edward Albert was invested and presented to the Welsh people as Prince of Wales at Caernarfon Castle, the first time in six hundred years. Welsh local authorities had asked that the red dragon might be introduced into the Royal arms and the coinage, but neither of these wishes were granted. However a year later in 1911, King George V issued an [[order in council]] that replaced the inescutcheon of Saxony, in the Arms of the Prince of Wales, with an inescutcheon with the arms "representing the Principality of Wales". Blazoned as: ''"Quarterly Or and Gules four lions passant guardant counterchanged, ensigned by the Coronet of His degree."''{{LondonGazette|issue=28473 |date=7 March 1911 |page=1939 }}Pinces & Pinces p. 273 In 1958 Prince Charles, the Duke of Cornwall, son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] was granted the same arms when he was made Prince of Wales.Pinces & Pinces p. 280 |- |} ==Family== ===Consorts=== The family of the Prince of Wales is entitled to use certain heraldic features. The consort of the Prince of Wales (titled the [[Princess of Wales]]) is granted a unique coat of arms upon marriage, based on the [[Impalement (heraldry)|impaling]] of the prince's arms (on the dexter side) and her father's arms (on the sinister side). The consort is also entitled to use the prince's supporters (with the appropriate label) and the use of the prince's coronet over the arms. The current consort; [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla]], the [[Duchess of Cornwall]], was granted a coat of arms on 17 July 2005 upon her marriage to Charles, Prince of Wales.{{cite web |url=https://www.princeofwales.gov.uk/biographies/hrh-duchess-cornwall |title=HRH The Duchess of Cornwall: Titles and Heraldry |accessdate=2018-10-09 |work=Official website of the Prince of Wales}}
{| class="wikitable" |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Augusta of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg, Princess of Wales.svg|200px]]
|
[[File:Coat of Arms of Alexandra of Denmark as Princess of Wales.svg|200px]]

{| class="wikitable" |- |
[[File:Coat of Arms of Diana, Princess of Wales (1981-1996).svg|200px]]

[[Diana, Princess of Wales|Diana Spencer]]
(wife of [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Charles]], 1981 – 1996)

===Children=== The children of the heir apparent were given their own distinct coronet, unlike any other grandchildren of the sovereign. This was confirmed in the 1917 Royal Warrant, which proclaimed: ''"to all the sons and daughters of the son and heir apparent of us and of our successors a coronet composed of two [[Cross pattée|crosses pattée]] (or crosses formy) four fleurs-de-lis and two strawberry leaves."''{{cite web |url=https://www.college-of-arms.gov.uk/news-grants/grants/item/71-coat-of-arms-prince-william |title=The Coat of Arms of HRH Prince William of Wales |accessdate=2018-10-09 |work=Official website of the College of Arms}} The wives of the sons of the Prince of Wales use the same coronet as their husbands. Such as arms borne by [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], which was granted to her in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.dukeandduchessofcambridge.org/the-duchess-of-cambridge/titles-and-heraldry/coat-of-arms-0 |title=Coat of Arms of Duchess of Cambridge |publisher=dukeandduchessofcambridge.org |date=14 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106071755/http://www.dukeandduchessofcambridge.org/the-duchess-of-cambridge/titles-and-heraldry/coat-of-arms-0 |archivedate=6 November 2012 |accessdate=2018-08-10 |df= }}
