The '''Frank Gardiner–Ben Hall Gang''' was an informal group of [[bushranger]]s who roamed the central west of [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]] in the 1860s. The gang was responsible for the largest gold robbery in Australia’s history at [[Eugowra, New South Wales|Eugowra Rocks]]. The gang had its origins in 1861; its demise came with the execution of [[John Dunn (bushranger)|John Dunn]] in 1866.
==Known members and fate== *John Peisley: Hanged *[[Frank Gardiner]]: Sentenced to 32 years in prison (served 10 years and then exiled from Australia) *[[John Gilbert (bushranger)|John Gilbert]]: Shot dead by police *John Davis, one of the '''Three Jacks''': Sentenced to 15 years in prison *John McGuiness, one of the '''Three Jacks''': Shot dead (probably by Gardiner for leaving Davis alone to fight police) *John Connors, one of the '''Three Jacks''': *[[Ben Hall (bushranger)|Ben Hall]]: Shot dead by police *John Youngman: Skipped bail and disappeared. *[[Patrick Daley]]: Sentenced to fifteen years in prison *Henry Manns: Hanged *Alexander Fordyce: Sentenced to death, later commuted to fifteen years in prison *Dan Charters: Caught, testified against the gang *John Bow: Sentenced to death, later commuted to fifteen years in prison *[[John O’Meally]]: Shot dead *[[Fred Lowry]]: Shot dead *[[Larry Cummins]]: Sentenced to fifteen years in prison *Francis Foley (younger brother of notorious bushranger, [[John Foley (Bushranger)|John Foley]]): Sentenced to ten years in prison *Michael Burke: Shot himself dead after receiving a mortal stomach wound *[[John Vane (bushranger)|John Vane]]: Sentenced to fifteen years in prison, paroled after six years *John Dunleavy: Sentenced to life in prison *Jin Gordon, AKA ''Old Man'' James Mount: sentenced to twenty five years in prison *[[John Dunn (bushranger)|John Dunn]]: Hanged *William Woodhart: ran with Lowry and Gardiner, after escaping with Lowry from Bathurst Gaol on 13 Feb 1863. Captured in Braidwood May 1863. Sentence: 3 Years, on top of previous 5 years sentence for horse stealing.
== Gang activities ==
John Peisley was born at Bathurst in 1835. While a teenager, he became a notorious horse thief in the area. He was convicted and sentenced to serve time on Cockatoo Island near [[Sydney]], where he met [[Frank Gardiner]]. In December 1860, Peisley gained his [[ticket of leave]], on the condition that he remain in the [[Hunter Region|Hunter River Valley]] area. He absconded to the Abercrombie Ranges, where his parents once lived, and became a lone [[highwayman|highway robber]], "sticking up" travellers in the area south and west of [[Bathurst, New South Wales|Bathurst]].
Gardiner was granted a ticket of leave in December 1859 on the condition of staying in the [[Carcoar, New South Wales|Carcoar]] district, and he soon joined up with Peisley. [[John Gilbert (bushranger)|Johnny Gilbert]] joined them soon afterwards, and the gang started stealing cattle and horses. Gardiner's [[ticket of leave]] was revoked when a warrant for his arrest for cattle stealing was issued.
Gardiner had a partnership with William Fogg in a butcher shop at Spring Creek. Gardiner supplied Fogg with stolen cattle, and Fogg would slaughter the cattle and sell the meat.
===1861=== *May: Gardiner, Peisley and Gilbert robbed mail in [[Cowra, New South Wales|Cowra]]. *16 July: Sgt. John Middleton and Constable William Hosie went to Fogg's house in search of Gardiner. He was briefly captured after a gunfight, but he was rescued by Peisley and John Gilbert, who ambushed the police on their return to town. *25 December: Peisley shot William Benyon, who died seven days later.
===1862=== *29 January: Peisley was captured and committed for trial by the Carcoar bench for murdering an innkeeper at [[Bigga, New South Wales|Bigga]]. Within two months he was convicted and hanged at Bathurst. *January: "The Three Jacks" – Davis, McGuinness, and Connors – committed their first robberies with Gardiner. *10 April: Davis was wounded four times by police near [[Young, New South Wales|Lambing Flat]]. His companions, the other two Jacks, escaped. *13 April: McGuiness was found dead near where Davis was captured; he had been shot. *14 April: Gardiner, Hall, Youngman, and Gilbert robbed [[Wagon|dray]] near [[Forbes, New South Wales|Forbes]]. In 1862, John Gilbert was first named as an accomplice of Gardiner when they and two others held up a storekeeper. Just over a month later, John Gilbert was involved in another robbery, this time with Gardiner and Ben Hall. From then on John Gilbert was identified as being involved in several hold-ups between Lambing Flat and Lachlan. *25 April: Peisley was hanged in Bathurst. [[Image:Escort Rock near Eugowra NSW.jpg|thumb|left|the location of the robbery at Eugowra Rocks]] *15 June: Frank Gardiner enlisted the assistance of John Gilbert, Ben Hall, John O'Meally, Dan Charters, Henry Manns, Alexander Fordyce, and Johnny Bow to rob the Forbes gold escort, at a place called [[Eugowra, New South Wales|Eugowra Rocks]], of banknotes and 2700 ounces of gold worth more than £14,000. *27 July: Hall and several others were arrested. Charters turned [[Queen's evidence]] but failed to name Hall or O'Meally. *23 August: Hall was released. Gardiner left the district and moved to Queensland.
===1863=== *1 January: Fred Lowry shot a man whilst robbing the Brisbane Valley races (near the head of Fish River Creek) with John Foley. Lowry robbed settlers at Wambanamba. Lowry shot John Mcbride, who died from his leg wound. * 13 February: Fred Lowry had been captured and placed in Bathurst Jail. On Feb 13 he had a mattock secreted into the jail and smashed a hole in the jail wall. Five prisoners escaped. Three escapees were caught that day. Fred Lowry and William Woodhart escaped capture. Lowry and Woodhart joined up with Gardiner. *12 May: William Woodhart caught at Fowlow by Senior Constable Reilly and brought into Braidwood. *13 July: Johnny Gilbert and John O'Meally, led by Ben Hall, held up the Commercial Bank at Carcoar. A brave teller in the bank fired a shot into the ceiling of the bank, thwarting the robbery. The manager was shot outside the bank as he was returning to the bank, and the gang fled without seizing anything. This was Australia's first bank robbery, and it took place in broad daylight. *13 July: Lowry, with Cummins and John Foley, robbed the [[Mudgee, New South Wales|Mudgee]] mailcoach. *August: John O'Meally shot dead John Barnes, a shopkeeper near [[Wallendbeen, New South Wales|Wallendbeen]]. *30 August: Fred Lowry died from wounds after a shootout with police at [[Crookwell, New South Wales|Crookwell]] the night before. Cummins was arrested. *7 September: Francis Foley was sentenced to ten years "on the roads", with the first year in irons. Francis' brother, John Foley, was sentenced on the same day to fifteen years hard labour, with the first three in irons. *23 September 1863, Patrick Daley sentenced to fifteen years on the roads *27 September: First raid on Canowindra. *1 October: John Gilbert, Ben Hall, John O’Meally, and two Mount Macquarie lads, John Vane and Micky Burke, held up a jeweller’s shop and the Sportsman’s Arms Hotel in Bathurst in broad daylight. They exchanged shots with police as they made their escape down George Street. Three days later they returned to rob more stores, houses, and hotels on the outskirts of the town. *12 October: Hall and his gang bailed up Robinson's Hotel in [[Canowindra, New South Wales|Canowindra]] and held all the people of the town captive for three days. The hostages were allegedly not mistreated, and were provided with entertainment. The local policeman was subjected to humiliation by being locked in his own cell. When the hostages were set free, the gang insisted on paying the hotelier and giving the townspeople "expenses". *24 October: Twenty-year-old Michael Burke’s bushranging career ended at Rockley. Holding up Gold Commissioner Keightley, he was wounded in the stomach and, believing he was about to die, shot himself in the head. While he was still alive and in pain, one of his friends killed him (the coroner named Hall as the person who fired the shot). *3 November: Third raid on Canowindra. *18 November: John Vane surrendered to police. Vane was sentenced to fifteen years; he was released in 1870. *19 November: John O'Meally was shot dead during a raid on Goimbla station. *December: Dunleavy and Mount joined the gang.
===1864===
*24 March: Frank Gardiner was living at Apis Creek near [[Rockhampton]], Queensland, where he was running a general store. He was recognised and reported to the police in Sydney. Gardiner was arrested and taken back to Sydney, and sentenced to 32 years hard labour.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/30938549?searchTerm=frank%20gardiner&searchLimits= |title=Capture of Frank Gardiner the Highwayman |date=21 March 1864 |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date=24 January 2013 |via=[[Trove]]}}</ref> *16 June: William Fogg Sentenced to 7 years hard labor at Yass Quarter Sessions for maliciously killing cattle.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/60840719 |title=The Empire. |newspaper=[[Empire (newspaper)|Empire]] |location=Sydney, NSW |date=31 May 1867 |access-date=2 June 2015 |page=4 |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]] |via=[[Trove]]}}</ref> *25 September: The gang robbed a mail coach near [[Yass, New South Wales|Yass]]. *October: Dunleavy and Mount were arrested by police; Dunn joined Ben Hall's gang. *15 November: The gang robbed the Gundagai Mail near [[Jugiong, New South Wales|Jugiong]] and Gilbert shot Sergeant Parry dead.<ref name=career>{{cite news |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=BH18660215.2.13 |title=Career of Dunn the Bushranger |newspaper=Bruce Herald |volume=III |issue=98 |page=5|date=15 February 1866 |access-date=25 December 2010 |via=[[Papers Past]]}}</ref> *26 December: Hall, Gilbert, and Dunn bail up the town of [[Binda, New South Wales|Binda]]. Hall burned down Morriss’s store as an act of revenge after Morriss escaped and alerted police.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tablelandsway.com.au/experience-trails/bushrangers-of-upper-lachlan/ |title=Bushrangers of Upper Lachlan |access-date=23 August 2018 |work=The Tablelands Way |publisher=[[Department of Resources, Energy and Tourism]], [[Australian Government]] |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20100430022752/http://www.tablelandsway.com.au:80/experience-trails/bushrangers-of-upper-lachlan/ |archive-date=30 April 2010}}</ref>
===1865=== *26 January: Hall, Gilbert, and Dunn were at [[Collector, New South Wales|Collector]], near [[Lake George (New South Wales)|Lake George]]. Dunn twice shot and killed the local police officer, Constable Samuel Nelson, the sole policeman in the township and father of eight children, while Hall and Gilbert were holding up the hotel. Dunn also shot at one of Nelson's sons but missed. [[Image:CaptureofBenHall.jpg|right|thumb|Death of Ben Hall]] *3 February: Robbed the Murrumbah Inn and the Ploughed Ground Inn at Paddys River. *6 February: Robbed the Braidwood mail coach south of Goulburn. *24 February: Shootout with police at Byrnes’ farm in Mutbilly. *4 March: Robbed the Gundaroo mail coach at Gearys Gap. *13 March: The gang attempted to rob the Araluen escort at Majors Creek. *17 March: The gang robbed Chinese miners at Little Wombat. *18 March: The gang exchanged shots with police at Wallendbeen; Gilbert was wounded in the arm. *25 March: Robbed Jones’s store at Forbes. *9 April: Robbed Brazier’s Inn at Nubryan. *10 April: Robbed Watts’s Inn, Austin’s inn, and Gallimore’s store at Black Rock. *21 April: The gang robbed Yamma Station. *May: Hall, Gilbert, and Dunn were proclaimed outlaws. The ''[[Felons Apprehension Act 1865|Felons Apprehension Act]]'' was passed, which allowed known [[bushrangers]] to be shot and killed rather than taken to trial. This put the members of the gang outside the law and liable to be killed by anyone. *5 May: Hall had separated from the other two and later was surrounded by police and shot dead in the bush near Forbes . *12 May: Gilbert and Dunn, on hearing the news of Hall's death, headed for Dunn's grandfather's property at Murrumbarrah.
[[Image:JohnGilbertGraveInfo.JPG|thumb|right]]
*13 May: The [[Binalong, New South Wales|Binalong]] Police Station Senior Constable Charles Hales thought they might visit John Kelly, Dunn's grandfather. On the morning of the 13th of May, John Kelly informed Senior Constable Hales that Gilbert and Dunn were at his hut. Hales gathered Constables John Bright, Michael King, and Henry Hall and headed to Kelly's place. Two parties were formed: Bright and Hall went to the back of the hut and were stationed in the creek, while Hales and King were stationed at the front of the hut.
:As Hales and King approached the hut, the dogs started barking. Bushrangers ran out the back of the hut firing their guns, and kept up the fire as they got through a bush fence that led to the creek. They positioned themselves behind a large tree. Gilbert fired his revolving rifle at Hales and Bright, but it misfired. Meanwhile, King and Hall took up positions. Dunn and Gilbert started firing their revolvers at Hall and King and ran down to the creek. Hales and Bright immediately fired at the bushrangers; Gilbert was shot and died instantly.
:Hales ordered his men to follow and to chase Dunn. The three constables chased Dunn for about a mile and a half; they were exhausted and had to give up the pursuit. Dunn stole a horse from nearby Bogolong station and wasn't heard from again for seven months.
*18 December: Dunn was recognized by Police at McPhails Station near [[Walgett, New South Wales|Walgett]]. A week later on the 26th of December, after a gunfight with police, he was wounded and captured near [[Coonamble, New South Wales|Coonamble]].<ref name=career/> He was tried on 19 January 1866; the jury took ten minutes to find him guilty of murder, and he was sentenced to hang. He was hanged in [[Darlinghurst Gaol]] on 19 March 1866.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/18702710 |title=Execution of Dunn |date=22 March 1866 |newspaper=[[The Maitland Mercury & Hunter River General Advertiser]] |access-date=24 January 2013 |via=[[Trove]] |publisher=[[National Library of Australia]]}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Frank Gardiner, the King of the Road]] *[[The Life and Adventures of John Vane, the Notorious Australian Bushranger]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == *[https://archive.is/20121231072337/http://www.nedkellysworld.com.au/bushrangers/gilbert_j.htm Biography of Gilbert] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071011033455/http://www.bdm.nsw.gov.au/familyHistory/benHall.htm Death certificate - New South Wales Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages] *[http://www.wilmap.com.au/bushrangers/hall.html Ben Hall Bushranger] *[http://www.benhall.net.au/ The Story of Ben Hall] *[http://nma.gov.au/exhibitions/irish_in_australia/bushrangers/ Ben Hall on the National Museum of Australia website]

page.title: Gallery of head of government standards

revision.text:

{{lead too short|date=December 2011}}
The '''Irvine''' family were agricultural pioneers and prominent [[landowner]]s in California who gave their name to the city of [[Irvine, California]].
==James Irvine I== '''James Irvine''' (1827–1886) was born in [[County Down]], [[Ireland]] on December 27, 1827, the second to the youngest of nine children. When [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Ireland's potato crop failed]] in 1845, James Irvine and his younger brother William were among those who left for the [[United States]]. The family name is Scottish, meaning that James would have been an [[Ulster Scots people|Ulster Scot]], or [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]]. Irvine worked for two years in [[New York City]]. In 1848 Irvine went to join the [[California Gold Rush]] as a merchant and miner. In 1854, he purchased an interest in a [[San Francisco]] commission house on Front Street, operated by a relative, John Lyons. The business was renamed "Irvine & Co., wholesale produce and grocery merchants". He began investing his profits in income-producing San Francisco real estate and soon became a wealthy man. Irvine also became a silent partner in the sheep-raising venture [[Flint, Bixby & Company]] of brothers Thomas and Benjamin Flint, and their cousin [[Bixby land companies|Llewellyn Bixby]]. The purchase of the {{convert|48800|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Rancho San Joaquin]] in 1864 and the {{convert|47200|acre|km2|adj=on}} [[Rancho Lomas de Santiago]] in 1866 marked the beginning of their operations in Southern California. In 1867, Irvine married Henrietta Maria (Nettie) Rice, the daughter of prominent [[Cleveland, Ohio]], educator, writer, poet and State Senator [[Harvey Rice]], who was a direct descendant of [[Edmund Rice (1638)|Edmund Rice]].<ref>[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=kt5779q2gb&chunk.id=bioghist-1.8.3&brand=oac Guide to the Rice Family Papers]</ref> Nettie died in 1874, and Irvine married Margaret Byrne in 1880. He died March 15, 1886, and is buried in San Francisco.<ref>''Notables Of The West V2: Being The Portraits And Biographies Of The Progressive Men Of The West'', 1915, by International News Service</ref>
==James Irvine II== '''James Harvey Irvine, Sr.''' (1867–1947), son of James Irvine I and [[Harvey Rice|Henrietta Maria (Nettie) Rice]], was born October 16, 1867, in San Francisco.<ref name=Blue>[[Thomas William Herringshaw|Herringshaw, Thomas William]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=kykEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA293 ''American Elite and Sociologist Bluebook'', p. 293.] American Blue Book Publishers, 1922.</ref> His mother died when he was seven years old, and his father died when he was about eighteen. Between the time of James Irvine I's death in 1886 and James Irvine II's inheritance of the Southern California real estate holdings upon his twenty-fifth birthday in 1892, the properties were supervised by James Irvine I's brother, George Irvine. James II bought out Flint and the other partners, and formed the [[Irvine Company]]. He married Frances Anita Plum in 1892, and they had three children, "Jase", James Harvey Irvine Jr. (1894–1935), Katharine Helena Irvine (1894–1920) and Myford Plum Irvine (1898–1959). In 1931, James II married Mrs. Kathryn Brown White, who died in 1950.<ref>Cleland, Robert Glass. The Irvine Ranch of Orange County: 1810-1950. San Marino, Calif.: The Huntington Library, 1952, p. 147.</ref> James II lived in San Francisco until the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]], when he relocated to the Irvine Ranch. He was a member of the [[Bohemian Club]], and kept a residence in San Francisco, at 2421 Pierce Street.<ref name=Blue/> He established the [[James Irvine Foundation]] in 1937, an entity dedicated to the "general well-being of the citizens and residents of the state of California." James II owned nearly a third of the land in present-day [[Orange County, California|Orange County]]. The city of [[Irvine, California|Irvine]] (formerly Myford) is named after him. He died of [[Bright's disease]] in 1947.<ref>[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~npmelton/sfbirvi.htm James Irvine II]</ref>
==James Irvine III== '''James Harvey Irvine, Jr.''' (1894–1935) was groomed since a young man to take over the Ranch. He married Madeline Agassiz in 1914, but they were divorced in 1928. He married Athalie Richardson (1903–1993) in 1929, and they had one daughter, Athalie Anita "Joan" Irvine (1933– ). When James Irvine III died of tuberculosis in 1935, James II set up the James Irvine Foundation, a charitable organization to hold controlling stock in the Irvine Company. When James II died in 1947, Myford Plum Irvine (1898–1959),<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSmid=1380347&GRid=8286758& Myford Plum Irvine @ find a grave]</ref> James II's only surviving child, took over the presidency of the Irvine Company.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brower |first=Martin A |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Irvine Ranch : a time for people : a 50-year overview of the development of the Irvine Ranch |year=1994 |publisher= |quote= | url= |isbn=978-0-9641326-0-3 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Cleland |first=Robert Glass |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Irvine Ranch |year= 2003|publisher= The Huntington Library Classics|quote= | url= |isbn=978-0-87328-015-0 }} </ref>

'''Keaweaweʻulaokalani''' is a name shared by two short-lived princes and heirs to the throne of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. Both were named after their father [[Kamehameha III]]. In [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], the name means "the red trail of heaven", signifying the roadway by which the god descends from heaven.
==Earlier== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani I | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = 1839 | birth_place = | death_date = 1839 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani I''' (1839–1839) was the eldest son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was named after his father whose full name was Keaweawe{{okina}}ula Kiwala{{okina}}o Kauikeaouli Kaleiopapa Kalani Waiakua Kalanikau Iokikilo Kiwala{{okina}}o i ke kapu Kamehameha. The royal suffix o-Kalani was added in to signified this Prince of [[Heaven]].
The young Prince Keawe died shortly after his birth. His death left Kamehameha III again childless. His younger brother, Keaweaweʻulaokalani II, would not be born until 1842.
==Later== {{Infobox royalty | name = Keaweaweʻulaokalani II | title = Prince of Hawaii | house = [[House of Kamehameha]] | father = [[Kamehameha III]] | mother = [[Kalama]] | birth_date = January 14, 1842 | birth_place = | death_date = February 1842 | death_place = |}} '''Keaweaweʻulaokalani II''' (1842–1842) was the second son of [[Kamehameha III]] and his queen consort [[Kalama Hakaleleponi-i-Kapakuhaili]]. The baby boy was the namesake of his father and his brother.
Initially given in ''[[hānai]]'' to [[Kalākua Kaheiheimālie]], he was instead adopted or ''hānai'' by his grand aunt, [[Kekāuluohi]] and her husband [[Charles Kanaina|Kana{{okina}}ina]] when the old governess of Maui died not three days after his birth. The King promised that he would be sent to the [[Chiefs' Children's School]] once he was weaned and could walk. He soon developed a fever and died, at the age of only 31 days. Dr. Baldwin of Lahaina was convinced that the child was killed by traditional medicinal treatment.

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Lambeth slavery case | location = [[Lambeth]], [[South London]], [[England]] | date = {{spaced ndash}}25 October 2013 | time = | timezone = | coordinates = | type = [[Slavery]], [[domestic servitude]] | victims = {{Plainlist| * Aishah Wahab<ref name="Sawer">Patrick Sawer, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/10486213/How-Chairman-Mao-of-Brixton-built-his-sect-of-slaves.html "How Chairman Mao of Brixton built his sect of 'slaves’"], telegraph.co.uk, 2013</ref> * Josephine Herivel<ref>Martin Evans, et al [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10476943/Irish-slave-revealed-as-daughter-of-Bletchley-Park-code-breaking-hero.html "Irish 'slave' revealed as daughter of Bletchley Park code breaking hero "], telegraph.co.uk, 26 November 2013</ref> * Rosie Morgan-Davies<ref name="Sawer"/>
}} | susperps = {{Plainlist| * Aravindan Balakrishnan * Chanda Balakrishnan }} }} On 21 November 2013 [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] from the [[National Crime Agency#Organisational Structure|Human Trafficking Unit]] arrested two suspects at a residential address in [[Lambeth]], [[South London]]. A 73-year-old ethnic Indian [[Singaporean]] man, Aravindan Balakrishnan, and a 67-year-old [[Tanzanian]]<ref name = "growing up"/> woman, his wife, Chanda Pattni, had been investigated for [[slavery]] and [[domestic servitude]].<ref name="Halliday"/><ref name="Standard"/> The case centred around the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]] commune which was led by Balakrishnan. In the early 1980s after a police raid, Balakrishnan decided to move the group's activities underground. Balakrishnan's control over his followers intensified and the commune became a prison to his followers. On 25 October 2013, three women were rescued from the commune. These were: a 69-year-old [[Malaysians in the United Kingdom|Malaysian]] woman (later revealed to be Aishah Wahab),<ref name="Sawer"/> a 57-year-old [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] woman (Josephine Herivel) and a 30-year-old [[United Kingdom|British]] woman (Katy Morgan-Davies).<ref name="Standard">{{cite news |title=Women victims 'held for 30 years' |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/panewsfeeds/women-victims-held-for-30-years-8954976.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> Katy Morgan-Davies was born into the sect and hadn't experienced the outside world until her release.
==Perpetrator== '''Aravindan Balakrishnan''' (known to his followers as "'''Comrade Bala'''") was born in [[Kerala]], [[India]] but migrated to [[Singapore]], [[British Malaya|Malaya]], where his father was a soldier, when he was 10.<ref name="Ward-Tele">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Aravindan Balakrishnan: the Maoist cult leader who used brutal violence and rape to strip women of their dignity|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12031312/Aravindan-Balakrishnan-the-Maoist-cult-leader-who-used-brutal-violence-and-rape-to-strip-women-of-their-dignity.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=4 December 2015}}</ref> Balakrishnan was a student at [[Raffles Institution]] and later the [[University of Singapore]], where although gaining a reputation as a "quiet chap",<ref name="Reuters-AO">{{cite news|author1=Reuters|title=UK Maoist cult leader raped followers, enslaved daughter|url=http://www.asiaone.com/world/uk-maoist-cult-leader-raped-followers-enslaved-daughter|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=AsiaOne|date=13 November 2015}}</ref> he became increasingly politically active and believed that he would have been imprisoned in Singapore had he openly admitted to being a [[communist]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In 1977, while living in London, His Singaporean citizenship – which he gained in 1960 – was revoked due to his leadership of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]], which the [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Singapore)|Ministry of Home Affairs]] accused of engaging in "activities which are prejudicial to the security" of Singapore, and denounced him as a radical "closely associated with [[Eurocommunists]]".<ref name="Reuters-AO" /> The authorities claimed that Balakrishnan and others, many of them former Singaporean students he had associated with in London, were plotting to overthrow Singapore's leader, [[Lee Kuan Yew]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
Despite believing the United Kingdom to be a [[fascist state]] due to its treatment of the people of Singapore during the [[Malayan Emergency]], Balakrishnan emigrated to the UK in 1963 on a [[British Council]] scholarship to study at the [[London School of Economics]], and married his wife Chandra in 1971.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Over the years he built up a following by giving lectures and staging various [[sit-in]]s and protests. He was a regular attendee at [[London]] demonstrations, where he waved banners depicting the Chinese leader [[Mao Zedong]] and addressed the crowds.<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
In 1974, Balakrishnan and his "small clique" were expelled from the [[Communist Party of England (Marxist–Leninist)]] on account of "their pursuance of conspiratorial and [[wikt:splittist|splittist]] activities ... spreading [[social fascist]] slanders against the Party and the proletarian movement" and attempting "to put themselves above the discipline of the Party".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement">[http://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/cpestatements.htm "Statements of the National Executive Committee, CPE (ML)"], ''The Marxist-Leninist'', 1:1, September 1974, reprinted at marxists.org. Quoted in Nick Cohen [http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/nick-cohen/2013/11/cultists-communists-too-close-to-us-for-comfort/ "Cultists & communists – too close to us for comfort"], ''The Spectator'' (blog), 25 November 2013</ref> The CPE(M–L) "repudiated the metaphysical logic harmfully promoted" by Balakrishnan in "opposition to dialectical materialism and the concrete analysis of concrete conditions".<ref name="CPE(M-L) statement"/> In response, Balakrishnan set up the Workers' Institute and launched his own publication, the ''South London Workers' Bulletin'', which accused the CPE(M–L) of being "fascists" and "agents of imperialism".<ref name="Ford-WW-989">{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=Eddie|title=Maoist 'slaves': Combating the fascist state in Brixton - Weekly Worker|url=http://weeklyworker.co.uk/worker/989/maoist-slaves-combating-the-fascist-state-in-brixt/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Weekly Worker|issue=989|date=5 December 2013}}</ref>
Between 1974 and 1976, his followers attempted to "build revolutionary stable base areas in working-class communities",<ref name="On Building a">{{cite news|author1=Workers’ Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought|title=On Building a Revolutionary Stable Base Area|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/stable-base.htm|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line|year=1977}}</ref> primarily [[South London]], and worked in ordinary jobs. Balakrishnan discouraged his followers from joining [[trade unions]], describing them as agents of the "imperialist fascist bourgeoisie".<ref name="Smith-Conv">{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Evan|title=Inside the paranoid Maoist cults of 1970s Britain|url=http://theconversation.com/inside-the-paranoid-maoist-cults-of-1970s-britain-20739|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Conversation|date=28 November 2013}}</ref>
Eventually, after the more liberal members of his group drifted away, a cult of around 10 female members formed around him. The collective moved to Brixton in 1976, under the title [[Workers Institute of Marxism-Leninism-Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Following [[Mao Zedong#Death and aftermath|Mao's death in 1976]], the Institute built the Mao Zedong Memorial Centre at 140 Acre Lane, [[Brixton]], which also functioned as a communist collective of "thirteen comrades", with "13 members living on the premises, half in paid work, six doing full-time revolutionary work, with a strong emphasis on women taking a leading role (apart from leading the Party Committee headed by Bala)".<ref name="On Building a" /><ref name="Smith-Conv" /><ref>{{cite news|title=High Tide: The Consolidation of Maoism by the Late 1970’s|url=https://www.marxists.org/history/erol/uk.hightide/|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Encyclopedia of Anti-Revisionism On-Line}}</ref> Members were handed a rota of chores and only allowed to go out in pairs, which Balakrishnan claimed was because the area they lived in was "notorious for violence" and "anything could happen".<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2">{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Victoria|title=Maoist 'cult' leader denies rape as he claims female commune members competed for his affections|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/12019410/Maoist-cult-leader-denies-rape-as-he-claims-female-commune-members-competed-for-his-affections.html|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=Telegraph|date=26 November 2016|language=en}}</ref>
Following a police raid on the Memorial Centre in March 1978, which the group claimed involved "over 200 police", including officers from the [[Special Patrol Group]], "under the pretext of searching for drugs", the Workers' Institute effectively went underground, with the remaining members being convinced to end all contact with others and maintain an intense level of secrecy.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Family members were later branded fascist agents and ostracised,<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> and Balakrishnan and his captives moved to a number of properties during this time as a means for him to escape detection from the authorities.<ref name="Smith-Conv" /> Balakrishnan convinced his followers that everything was controlled by him from the sun, the moon, wind and fires; that he could overthrow governments, control natural disasters, and make people live or die.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> In order to progress his cause, Balakrishnan invented "JACKIE" (an acronym for [[Jehovah]], [[Allah]], [[Christ]], [[Krishna]] and [[Eknath Easwaran|Immortal Easwaran]]) – a type of dangerous, mystical machine that monitored all thought and could control minds.<ref name="Cooke">{{cite news|last1=Cooke|first1=Rachel|title=My 30 years as prisoner of a London cult|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2017/jan/22/katy-morgan-davies-interview-balakrishnan-cult-brixton-survivor|accessdate=5 June 2017|work=The Guardian|date=22 January 2017}}</ref>
Balakrishnan began sexually abusing two of the women in 1979, often physically beating them and making others watch as he did so. All of the women were beaten and four (not including his wife) were said to have been sexually assaulted or engaged with sexual relations with him.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /> Balakrishnan forced the women to swallow his ejaculate as it was "the elixir of life", and claimed the women he sexually abused had been trying to seduce him out of "jealousy" for his lover.<ref name="Ward-Tele" /><ref name="Ward-Tele2" />
==Victims== *[[Katy Morgan-Davies]] - born in 1983, she was originally named Prem Maopinduzi Davies. She began calling herself "Rosie" in her teens. She has subsequently changed her name to Katy Morgan-Davies, after the American singer [[Katy Perry]]. She is the biological daughter of Balakrishnan and Sian Davies.<ref name = "growing up">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932|title=Growing up a prisoner in a cult|date=26 January 2017|accessdate=28 January 2017|author=Vanessa Engle|publisher=BBC}}</ref> Morgan-Davies was brought up entirely isolated from the outside world and never went to a nursery, school, dentist or doctor. She was not told who her parents were. The commune members taught her to read and write.<ref name=bbc2>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
*[[Sian Davies]] - in the early 1980s, after joining the commune, she had a sexual relationship with Balakrishnan. On Christmas Eve 1996, Morgan-Davies remembered seeing Davies bound and gagged on the living room for trying to escape. Later, she fell out of a top floor bathroom window and was taken to hospital. In hospital she suffered a rapid decline in her mental health and fell into a coma. She died eight months later. After the fall, her family were told she had gone to India to do charity work.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} At the time of Davie's death her daughter, Morgan-Davies, did not know she was her mother.
*[[Aishah Wahab]] - a [[Malaysians|Malaysian]] woman who moved to the United Kingdom at the age of 24 to study, joining the group shortly after.<ref name = "growing up"/> Aishah was reportedly so drawn in by Balakrishnan's Marxist rhetoric that she left her fiancé and moved in with the collective.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Oh Kar Eng]] - nurse from [[Malaysia]] who had followed Balakrishnan from the 1970s. She hit her head on a cupboard in 2001 and suffered a stroke. No medical treatment was allowed by the commune and she died the next day.{{r|bbc}} The police were not informed of the accident. Her family were not told about her cremation, and they were told the commune did not have their ashes when in fact they were in a lockup garage in West Norwood.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
*[[Josephine Herivel]] - known as Josie, was a violinist studying at the [[Royal College of Music]] before she joined the group.<ref name = "growing up"/> Her father, [[John Herivel]] was one of the [[Bletchley Park]] [[codebreakers]] who helped Britain and its allies win [[World War II]]. She is believed to have moved to London in the 1970s and disowned her family after becoming involved with the Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Herivel initiated the escape plan after becoming concerned with Morgan-Davies rapid weight loss (which was due to undiagnosed diabetes). Medical treatment was not permitted by the commune. Herivel secretly phoned a helpline after memorizing the number from a television program. Herivel has denounced the Balakrishnan sentencing, claiming he has been framed by the state.{{r|bbc}}
==Imprisonment and rescue== The two older victims are believed to have met Balakrishnan in [[London]] through, according to police, a shared political ideology,<ref name="Evans">Martin Evans [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/10472632/Slavery-case-suspects-named-as-former-Maoist-collective-leaders.html "Slavery case: suspects named as former Maoist collective leaders"], telegraph.co.uk, 25 November 2013</ref> as he was the leader of the [[Workers' Institute of Marxism–Leninism–Mao Zedong Thought]].<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/news/slave-house-couple-lambeth-leaders-1970s-political-cult 'Slave' house couple 'leaders of 1970s political cult'"], ''[[Channel 4 News]]'', 25 November 2013</ref> The women were not being physically restrained, but held by "invisible handcuffs" after being subjected to [[Mind control|brainwashing]], [[Psychological abuse|emotional abuse]] and [[physical abuse]] by their captors.<ref name="Standard_2">{{cite news |title=London slave women endured 30 years of beatings, brainwashing and emotional control |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/crime/london-slave-women-endured-30-years-of-beatings-brainwashing-and-emotional-control-8956001.html |publisher=London Evening Standard |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=Justin |last=Davenport}}</ref> The three women, who are not related, are said to have been held captive for more than 30 years with the youngest of the three thought to have spent her whole life in servitude.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |title=Women 'held as slaves for 30 years' |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-25040741 |publisher=BBC News |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> However it has not yet been established if she was born in the house from where she was rescued.<ref name="BBC"/> The police were tipped off by [[Freedom Charity]] who contacted police following a phone call they had received on 18 October, during which a woman stated that she'd been held unwillingly for more than 30 years.<ref name="Standard_2"/><ref name="Irish">{{cite news |title=Irishwoman raises alarm after being held captive ‘for decades’ in south London home |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/irishwoman-raises-alarm-after-being-held-captive-for-decades-in-south-london-home-29773908.html |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=Independent News & Media |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 }}</ref> [[Aneeta Prem]] of Freedom Charity confirmed that the Irish woman made contact with the charity after watching the [[ITV (TV channel)|ITV]] television documentary ''Forced to Marry'' about [[forced marriage]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Irish"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Lambeth 'slaves rescue': Woman 'called Freedom Charity after watching TV documentary on forced marriage' |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lambeth-slaves-rescue-woman-called-2836476 |work=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=23 November 2013 |accessdate=23 November 2013 |first=James |last=Robertson |first2=Mark |last2=Jefferies }}</ref> The women, who are said to be "highly traumatised", are now in safe accommodation.<ref name="BBC"/>
The two suspects were bailed until April 2014,<ref name="Shaw">Danny Shaw [https://twitter.com/DannyShawBBC/status/425657327706861568] twitter.com, 21 January 2014</ref> and were unable to return to the three-bedroom flat they rented from a housing association.<ref name="Evans"/>
On 11 December 2014, it emerged that Balakrishnan had been charged with offences relating to cruelty to a person under 16, four counts of rape and 17 counts of indecent assault. Balakrishnan appeared before Westminster magistrates on 17 December 2014.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-30431988 "Man charged in London 'slavery' inquiry"], BBC News, 11 December 2014</ref> His wife, Chanda Pattni, was released earlier in 2014, as there was considered to be insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction.<ref>Josh Halliday [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2014/dec/11/london-slavery-case-cps-charges-ravindan-alakrishnan "London ‘slavery’ case: CPS charges Aravindan Balakrishnan"], ''The Guardian'', 11 December 2014</ref>
Balakrishnan's trial started on 11 November 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/11990783/Maoist-cult-leader-kept-daughter-as-slave-in-south-London-for-30-years-court-hears.html |title=Maoist cult leader sexually assaulted followers and kept daughter as slave for 30 years, court hears |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date= 12 November 2015 |author=Gordon Rayner |accessdate= 26 November 2015}}</ref> During his trial, he acted as the only defence witness, and told jurors that a challenge to his leadership resulted in the 1986 [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster]], and that JACKIE was responsible for the death of a Malaysian prime minister and the election of [[Jeremy Corbyn]] as [[Leader of the Labour Party (UK)|Leader of the Labour Party]].<ref name="Ward-Tele" />
On 4 December 2015, Balakrishnan was convicted of child cruelty, false imprisonment, four counts of rape, six counts of indecent assault and two counts of assault.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/04/commune-leader-aravindan-balakrishnan-guilty-of-child-cruelty "Maoist cult leader guilty of child cruelty and sexual assaults"], ''The Guardian'', 4 December 2015</ref> On 29 January 2016, Balakrishnan was jailed for 23 years. <ref>{{Cite web|title = Maoist cult leader Aravindan Balakrishnan jailed for 23 years - BBC News|url = https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-35443423|website = BBC News|access-date = 2016-01-29|language = en-GB}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=bbc>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-b0af7ef5-1031-4e1f-a3ac-b3c21ef0f932</ref>
<ref name="Halliday">{{cite news |title=Three women rescued after 'decades of slavery' in south London home |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/21/women-rescued-decades-slavery-south-london |publisher=The Guardian |date=21 November 2013 |accessdate=21 November 2013 |first=Josh |last=Halliday |first2=Peter |last2=Walker}}</ref> }}

revision.comment: Added additional LINE retail store location
revision.text:
{{Infobox product | image = Line Friends logo.png | caption = | type = Characters | inventor = | inception = 2011 | manufacturer = [[Naver Corporation]] | available = Yes | url = {{URL|https://www.linefriends.com}} }}
'''Line Friends''' (stylized as '''LINE FRIENDS''') are featured characters based on the stickers from messaging app [[Line (software)|Line]]. It was released in 2011 by [[Line Corporation]], a [[Japan|Japanese]] subsidiary of the [[South Korea|South Korean]] internet search giant [[Naver Corporation]]. These characters are used in various products, animation, game, cafe, hotel and theme park. The brand is currently managed by its subsidiary Line Friends Corporation since 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/line-friends-has-plans-global-domination|title=Line Friends Has Plans for Global Domination {{!}} License! Global|website=www.licensemag.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/line-friends-to-open-first-official-us-store-in-new-yorks-time-square-in-july-300418236.html|title=LINE FRIENDS to Open First Official U.S. Store in New York's Time Square in July|last=FRIENDS|first=LINE|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/08/11/line-messaging-app-times-square-store/|title=A popular messaging app inspired Times Square’s latest tourist trap|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
The original characters were created by Kang Byeongmok, also known as "Mogi" in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.i-bait.com/read.php?num=5545&cataId=NLC017004|title=스마트 폰 속 이모티콘, 세상 밖으로|website=시사매거진 바이트|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressm.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=8738|title='라인(LINE)'은 일본製일까 한국製일까|website=프레스맨|language=ko|accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> [[File:LINE_Friend_Store_in_Hysan_Place_201510.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:LINE_Friend_Store_in_Hysan_Place_201510.jpg|thumb|Line Friends Store in [[Hysan Place]], [[Hong Kong]]|219x219px]]
Apart from its online store, physical stores have been opened in [[Taiwan]] ([[Taipei]]), [[New York City]] ([[Times Square]]), [[Seoul]], [[Tokyo]] ([[Harajuku]]), Bangkok (Siam Square), Shanghai, [[Los Angeles]] ([[Hollywood]]) and Hong Kong.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hysan.com.hk/how-line-captured-hong-kong-hearts/|title=How LINE captured Hong Kong hearts - Hysan Development Company Limited|date=2015-10-23|work=Hysan Development Company Limited|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://adage.com/article/digital/line-app-u-s-market-times-sq-store-line-friends-toys/309995/|title=Japanese Messaging App Tries to Crack the U.S.... With a Store for Plush Toys|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en}}</ref>
== Characters ==
=== LINE Friends/Brown & Friends === * '''Cony''', '''Brown''', '''Moon''' and '''James''' (added in 2011, fun fact, Brown is Canadian) * '''Boss''', '''Jessica''' and '''Sally''' (added in 2013) * '''Leonard''' and '''Edward''' (added in 2014) * Brown's younger sister '''Choco''' and her boyfriend '''Pangyo''' (added in 2016)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stuff.tv/sg/features/9-surprising-secrets-you-never-realised-about-your-favourite-line-friends|title=Meet the newest member of the Line Friends family|work=Stuff|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-SG}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/2016/04/11/line-friends-choco/#8164shp.guqd|title=Messaging app Line introduces new character to its cute family|last=Tan|first=Alicia|work=Mashable|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en}}</ref>
=== BT21 === [[File:BT21 logo.png|thumb|Logo of the ''BT21'' series.]] [[File:BT21 in Hong Kong Line Friends Store.jpg|thumb|197x197px|BT21 series in [[Apm (Hong Kong)|apm Mall]], [[Hong Kong]] Line Friends Store]]BT21 is the first presentation from ''Friends Creators,'' a project formed to create new characters for the Line Friends series. A South Korean boyband [[BTS (band)|BTS]] is the first artist of this project, and the main theme of this project is to show connection between BTS and Line Friends in terms of popularity in the world. It comprises 8 special characters by South Korean boyband [[BTS (band)|BTS]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bt21.com/about|title=About Project|work=BT21 official website}}</ref>The character designs are based on the members of the group.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/k-town/8006877/bts-line-friends-bt21-collab-new-fashion-emojis-k-pop|title=BTS' New BT21 Collab With Line Friends Blends Fashion, Emojis & K-Pop|work=Billboard|access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref> Videos of BTS designing BT21 are uploaded in BT21 YouTube Channel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCINr5W7cwW06ADtsszAToAw|title=BT21|work=YouTube}}</ref>
* '''Tata''' is a character that sometimes smiles. He is a curious, shapeshifting alien with a heart-shaped head and a blue body with yellow polka-dots. He was created by [[V (singer)|V]]. * '''Chimmy''' is a character that has his tongue out all the time. He is a passionate puppy who wears a yellow hoodie. He was created by [[Jimin (BTS)|Jimin]]. * '''Koya''' is a character that always sleeps. He is a thinker, blue koala with removable ears (they fall off when he is in shock). He was created by [[RM (rapper)|RM]]. * '''Mang''' is a character that loves to dance. His species is unknown due to the horse-faced mask with a heart-shaped nose he wears that hides his identity. He was created by [[J-Hope]]. * '''RJ''' is a character that loves to eat. He is a kind, white alpaca who wears a red scarf and He wears a grey parka when it’s cold. He was created by Jin. * '''Shooky''' is a character who is very savage. He is a naughty, little chocolate cookie who is scared and hates milk. He was created by [[Suga (rapper)|Suga]]. * '''Cooky''' is character who loves his body "like a temple". He is a cute but tough, pink bunny with one bold eyebrows and white heart-pattern tail who wants to be strong. He was created by Jungkook. * '''Van''' is Tata's giant space robot. Half of his body is grey with an "X" eye, and the other half is white with an "O" eye. He is BT21's protector, and was created by RM to represent BTS' fandom, A.R.M.Y.
On March 25, 2018, BT21 released a promotional video via their YouTube channel for a new project with Line Friends called ''PUZZLE STAR BT21'', a puzzle game for mobile devices.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=orssmSjNkkk|title=[BT21] PUZZLE STAR BT21 is coming!|work=YouTube|date=March 25, 2018|accessdate=May 12, 2018}}</ref> The game was released on April 2nd and reached 1 million downloads within two days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.invenglobal.com/articles/4760/line-friends-puzzle-star-bt21-hits-1-million-downloads-in-just-2-days-after-its-release|title=LINE Friends' PUZZLE STAR BT21 hits 1 million downloads in just 2 days after its release!|work=INVENGlobal|date=April 4, 2018|accessdate=April 7, 2018}}</ref> On April 27, Mediheal announced a collaboration with BT21 via their Twitter<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Mediheal_kr/status/989765298101276672|title= Say Hello? Mediheal x BT21|work=Mediheal Twitter|date=April 27, 2018}}</ref> that launched on June 1, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mbn.mk.co.kr/pages/news/newsView.php?news_seq_no=3547993|title=메디힐, 방탄소년단과 한번 더…`BT21 포인트 마스크` 출시(Medi-Heal, Bulletproof Boys and one more... Launched 'BT21 Point Mask')|language=korean|work=[[Maeil Broadcasting Network|MBN]]|date=June 1, 2018|accessdate=June 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zenithnews.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=116103|title=방탄소년단 ‘BT21’ X 메디힐, 마스크팩 출시 "글로벌 시장 시너지 기대"(Bulletproof Boy Scouts 'BT21' X Medi Hill, Mask Pack Released "Expected Synergies in Global Markets")|language=korean|work=Zenith News|date=June 1, 2018|accessdate=June 2, 2018}}</ref> BT21 collaborated with Converse, and on July 27, 2018, Converse launched a new version of Chuck Taylor All Star series on which BT21 characters are drawn. This special edition is available in offline stores in South Korea, China, Taiwan and HongKong as well as in online store.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bt21.com/with/converse2018|title=ConverseXBT21, BT21's first 2018 collaboration|work=Converse}}</ref><ref>cite web|url=https://m.post.naver.com/viewer/postView.nhn?volumeNo=16352269&memberNo=1972782&vType=VERTICAL|title=★컨버스 X BT21 콜라보레이션 발매정보★(information about the new release of ConverseXBT21)|language=korean|work=Naver post|date=July 23, 2018}}</ref> On July 27, the first day of selling, all products were sold out within 10 minutes, 30 minutes, and 1 hour and half in [[Naver (corporation)]] online store, in [[Converse (shoe company)]] online store, and in Line Friends online store respectively. Also, on the same day, more than 100 people were waiting in line to get shoes from offline stores in South Korea.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=105&oid=018&aid=0004160829|title=라인프렌즈 '컨버스 BT21 콜라보 신발’ 1.5시간 만에 온라인 완판 ('ConverseXBT21 Chuck Tayler All Star' was sold out in 1 hour and 30 minutes)|language=korean|date=July 29, 2018|work=eDaily (in Korean)}}</ref>On July 27, 2018, Hunt Innerwear released BT21XHunter Innerwear collaboration pajamas. These are available in both online and offline stores in South Korea.<ref>http://www.elandmall.com/dispctg/initBrandShop.action?brand_no=1690000259&disp_ctg_no=1807355454</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.newdaily.co.kr/site/data/html/2018/07/17/2018071700061.html|title=이랜드월드 헌트이너웨어, BT21 콜라보레이션 파자마 출시(Hunter Innerwear released BT21XHunter Innerwear Collaboration pajamas)|language=korean|work=Newdaily(biz.newdaily.co.kr)|date=July 17, 2018}}</ref>
BT21 stickers are available in not only [[Naver|Naver]] and [[Line (software)|Line]] but also [[Facebook|Facebook]] and [[Facebook messenger|Facebook messenger]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=arsmQLW9pRE|title=Stickers on Facebook! -Teaser|date=July 27, 2018|work=YouTube}}</ref>
Each member of [[BTS (band)]] wore each one's character costume and performed the song "Anpanman" from [[Love Yourself: Tear]] at 2018 BTS Prom Party.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vlive.tv/video/73031?channelCode=FE619|title=2018 BTS PROM PARTY -RE;VIEW & PRE;VIEW-|date=June 29, 2018|work=V Live (website)}}</ref> This performance is also known as BT21's debut performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HjwC2LzbKu4|title=[BT21] 2018 Debut Stage|date=July 3, 2018|work=YouTube}}</ref> BTS members also uploaded their pictures wearing BT21 pajamas on BTS official [[Twitter]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/BTS_twt|title=BTS_Twt|work=Twitter}}</ref>
== Animations == {{context|section|date=October 2015}} Two anime series, LINE OFFLINE and LINE TOWN, were produced in 2013, picturing the Line Friends as employees for the fictional Line Corporation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://jpninfo.com/31855|title=Love LINE Friends? Then Check Out its Fun Little Anime Series! – Japan Info|work=Japan Info|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3041578/how-japans-line-app-became-a-culture-changing-revenue-generat|title=How Japan’s Line App Became A Culture-Changing, Revenue-Generating Phenomenon|date=2015-02-19|work=Fast Company|access-date=2018-04-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Line Offline === Line Offline is an animated series created by [[Shogakukan Productions]], based on [[salaryman]] characters working at "Line Corporation". All 114 episodes last about three minutes. The series was aired from January 8, 2013, to October 1, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/04/07/line-offline/|title=Messaging App Line’s Kawaii Characters Get Their Own Cartoon Series In Japan – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-02}}</ref>
The episodes of Line Offline are not connected to each other. The idea behind the series is to represent the ordinary life of company employees (in this case Line's employees, that's why the series is called "Line Offline"), in which every small problem could lead to weird and funny situations that require some effort in order to restore the [[status quo]].
Most characters from Line Offline are part of Line's universe (the characters who are shown in the animated series are also Line Friends, and they can be seen by users in Line Messaging App and used as emoticons).

=== Line Town ===
==== Characters ==== * '''Cony''' (voiced by Aki Kanada in the Japanese dub and Sarah Hauser in the English dub) is a [[rabbit]] with a pleasant personality. She likes to go on a diet. * '''Brown''' is a [[bear]] who likes [[salmon]] a lot. He is silent, and has a crush on Cony. He becomes scary when he gets angry, and notes appears when he feels good. * '''Moon''' (voiced by [[Toshiyuki Morikawa]] in the Japanese dub and Michael Pizzuto in the English dub) is a [[manjū]]-shaped-headed man who loves the moon. His interest is playing video games. He sometimes tricks his friends when he is bored. His father is an [[adventurer]]. * '''James''' (voiced by [[Yūto Kazama]] in the Japanese dub and Daniel Garcia in the English dub) is a [[narcissist]] with long, blonde hair. He is obsessed with his appearance, and is afraid of high places. * '''Jessica''' (voice by [[Sachi Kokuryu]] in the Japanese dub and Catherine Fu in the English dub) is a [[cat]] who is knowledgeable about [[fashion]] and loves to [[Cooking|cook]] a lot. She is Cony's best friend. * '''Sally''' (voiced by [[Atsuko Enomoto]] in the Japanese dub and Catherine Fu in the English dub) is a [[Bird|chick]] who usually helps her friends. She often stays in the [[windmill]] [[tree hollow]] in the park. She likes [[karaoke]]. * '''Boss/Mister''' (voiced by [[Nobuo Tobita]] in the Japanese dub and Michael Pizzuto in the English dub) is an almost completely bald middle-aged man with glasses. He appears as many different identities in every episode. * '''Leonard''' (voiced by [[Megumi Han]]) is a little [[frog]] boy that looks up to Moon. He refers to Moon as an "elder brother". ("Longing For") * '''Edward''' is a green worm with a cap who often stays by Sally's side. * '''Cob Taro''' (voiced by [[Nobuo Tobita]]) is a [[cobra]] with a [[Mohawk hairstyle]] and an [[eye patch]] that escaped from the [[zoo]] and now has a part-time job at the [[Hamburger|burger]] shop. * '''Dorothy''' (voiced by [[Chie Kōjiro]]) is a [[Chicken|hen]] who likes to take [[gossips]]. Cony fears her. * '''Mr. Kinoko''' (voiced by [[Mitsuru Ogata]]) is a [[beaver]] who owns a [[mushroom]] dish restaurant and can cook mushroom dishes very well. ''Kinoko'' is the Japanese word for mushrooms.

page.title: List of 301 geniuses by IQ (Catharine Cox Miles)

revision.text:
The list of 301 geniuses by [[intelligence quotient]] below is an estimation by [[Catharine Cox Miles]] published in the "Early Mental Traits of Three Hundred Geniuses (12A-AII table)" during 1926.M. Cox, Catharine (1926). "Early Mental Traits of Three Hundred Geniuses (Genetic Studies of Genius Series)" (en inglés). Stanford University Press. pp. 60a-60f. Original estimate is based in the [[historiometric]] method of [[Francis Galton]] and the [[Stanford–Binet Intelligence Scales|Stanford Binet Scale]] I (1916). The list is corrected and actualized due the [[Flynn effect]] during 1916 to 2003 and contains a convertion of Stanford Binet to Weschler based in inverse error function formulas and rarity chart tables (16SD to 15SD)..James R. Flynn, Massive IQ Gains in 14 Nations: What IQ Tests Really Measure, Psychological Bulletin, 1987, Vol. 101, No. 2, pp. 171-191Kush, J. C. (2005). Review of the Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scales: Fifth Edition. In R. A. Spies & B. S. Plake (Eds.), The sixteenth mental measurements yearbook (pp. 979–984). Lincoln: University of Nebraska. Rarity example with erfc-1 formula to [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] IQ with Stanford Binet (16SD)ː
16 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{erfc}^{-1} \left( \frac{2}{14,400,000} \right) +100 =184 Rarity example with erfc-1 formula to [[Johann Wolfgang von Goethe]] IQ with Weschler (15SD)ː
15 \sqrt{2} \operatorname{erfc}^{-1} \left( \frac{2}{14,400,000} \right) +100 =179 {| class="wikitable sortable" border="|1" ! Genius ! Cox Miles estimation (1926)
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]1 (1916) ! [[Flynn effect]] 1916-1986
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]4 Scale (1986) ! [[Flynn effect]] 1986-2003
Based in [[Stanford-Binet|SB]]5 Scale (2003) ! SB5-[[Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale|WAIS]] convertion

A large number of [[authors]] choose to use some form of initials in their name when it appears in their literary work. This includes some of the most famous authors of the 20th century – [[D. H. Lawrence]], [[J. D. Salinger]], [[T. S. Eliot]], [[J. R. R. Tolkien]], etc. – and also a host of lesser-known writers.
